												I can't believe this game went unnoticed. At first, I was like "yeah, it's an ok FPS, with some jump scares. That's alright". But when you get the TMD and the seeker, WOW! The game reveals itself and is freaking awesome!The style borrows from Wolfenstein, Metro 2033 and a little dose of Bioshock, but still stays unique.The action scenes are very well directed and give you a thrill.The enemies have different hitting zones and will die according to where you shoot them (head, chest, leg, etc.)The scenario is rich and adds up to this excellent game.Even five years old now, the graphics are still up to the par.Excellent game, well worth the money.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												I always wanted to play this game and having just completed it I give it a score of 6/10. These days many publications give the impression that 7/10 is average but I dont agree with that so an average game to me is still 5/10.I get the impression that this was a game that had a low budget and perhaps had budget cuts along the way -potentially cutting back on some ideas / scope of the game etc. The unique time altering abilities never quite live up to their potential as the game doesn't give you enough interesting enemies / scenarios to produce that crazy sense of power. It is a shame as in the end I wasn't really excited when presented with a new time control ability - it just felt like another weapon that I had collected. The enemy A.I is not one of it's high points, infact there were several occassions where I had to basically jump about infront of enemies to get them to interact with me. This was not that big a deal though as the level design is very linear which means that the majority of enemy interactions are heavily scripted and this works well enough!!Having said all this I still recommend this game to you as I had fun with it in the way that one would watching a fun action movie. The developers did a fantastic job in delivering a great sense of atmosphere. At times moments were built to a high level of scary tension which did give me a fright!This game had a lot of potential which perhaps could have been lived up to in a sequel but alas 6 years have passed since it's release so it looks like one will never materialise.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												Singularity: Good Video Games.Let's talk about what made me happy:Pride of place in an FPS: Weapons. They are your primary means of interacting with other entities, and damn are they nice. Many of them are neat spins on regular ol' bread and butter guns, and that's okay, but the look and feel of some guns is just great. The minigun has brake pads around the barrel. The shotgun has this neat locking top pump action. The rifle has a fan that spins as you fire. The Railgun has a timed delay explosive charge. Aside from looking neato frito, they all feel damn great and tear guys up very nicely. The other side of this is the TMD, which has powers and upgrades meted out to it through the course of the game and is great fun to oof at when you hit dudes with it. Seriously I was apologizing to AI for blowing them off their shins and leaving the feet standing. It's pretty grisly.Speaking of AI, the enemies are neat too. You have monsters and tough monsters and soldiers and tough soldiers, but that's boiling things right down to sump. They all have their neat features,  You can shoot limbs off the creatures and they'll keep coming, sometimes even after they're ostensibly dead. Soldiers will hide behind bigger dudes and try and flank you, though it's standard tactics it's still fun to play with. Between monsters and soldiers, there's a nice gamut of enemies, but though the groups have a nice variety within themselves, it's the way they're placed through the game that's cool. You'll be fighting some monsters and suddenly soldiers will drop in on cleanup, or the guy you're shooting will be clawed from behind, and infighting hell breaks loose either way. It's always fun to be the one in the eye of the storm, and Singularity does it wonderfully.Let's talk design elements real quick, since Singularity has a bunch I really like. Found Story? Check. Audio logs, notes, interactive items, flashbacks, secrets, all of the good stuff. Oh, what's that, you want wordless little vignettes? You got them too. If you like exploring the world in your FPSs and being rewarded for that with tidbits, you'll feel right at home. Tagging -horror onto your game's genre might have been the "in" thing, but Singularity does the horror elements right. The opening hour or so is filled with jumps and scares, but not jumpscares. You're dropped here and there's noises and movement and OH GOD WHAT IS THAT KILL IT ♥♥♥♥. Give it another couple of hours and you'll be topping those guys left and right, but there's howls in the distance that make you a little uneasy. Most mutant enemies go through this cycle of unknown-scary-identified-understood-kill with impunity. You'll get to know their weaknessess and strategies, but not before feeling a little uneasy that you don't. Another thing I'd like to touch real quick is the set pieces, the kind of ones where you'll be talking about games to a friend and you'll say "Remember that one mission in Singularity, on the bridge, when you-" and they'll go "Yeaahhhh, that was so good!" They're money, all I need to say. +Fantastic design all aroundNeat writing and backstoryMemorable encounters throughout, including bossesHeaps of little unf-worthy touches-Some genericity in places (playing it safe?)Gets progressively linear-erPhase Ticks and SewersExpensive as hell for it's ageSingularity is worth playing through if only to get a crash course in what FPS games in the mid-2000s were like, since it cribs stuff from all it's neighbours while managing to remain it's own beast and being very good for it. It also layers some of it's own stuff on top of that, and is, in general, very good. Time well spent (HAH).

content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												Well, that was satisfying. This game liberally embraces and extends, and everything it copies, it makes better.At times, it looks like Fallout3 without the silliness (it also lets you inspect a metric ton of flavor notes and recordings); it has a bit of a Half-Life 2 feel ("scifi settings + mute protagonist + gravity gun equivalent"), but much better pacing (and you don't want to kill the Alyx equivalent), and because of the whole "time" shtick, you justifiably get bullet time (as a slowdown with the regular sniper gun, and as a harder to explain, but immensely satisfying "slowdown + bulletcam + bullet control that lets you bend the path of the bullet around obstacles and corners" with the experimental sniper rifle, the "Seeker."), and of course the combination of "spookiness, Russia, anomalies" suggests comparisons with the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series.Other than that, it has a late '80s/early '90s flair to it; nihilistic scifi played straight, by the numbers shooter with solid mechanics, etc.As for the "time manipulation device", that's a really nice addition to the game that sets it apart. While you can only use it to time travel when you find a "rift" (at which point you can travel back to the time it was created), you can use the TMD to age/youth objects (and later enemies) quite often, sometimes in the context of simple but satisfying puzzles. Some reviews imply that the TMD is under-utilized (making me expect something like Remember Me where they made a big deal out of the memory remixing which then only appears in the game four or five times) -- not so. Or arguably, so but only if you look only at time travel and ignore object manipulation.Things to consider:- The game isn't that long and can be finished within a day / two evenings. I appreciate manageable commitment in a game; you may not. (Even then the sale price of around $3 is more than fair.)- The number of enemy types is somewhat limited. I find that to usually make a setting more believable, you may find it repetitive.- The number of boss fights is also very limited (but at least one of them has a nice setup, even if the actual fight is a bit by the numbers).- The game feels extremely linear. It's not outright painful (a la "I am alive"), but it's quite noticeable. Sure, it could be argued that that goes for all non-sandboxy games and that after the paradigm shift of open world, there's no satisfactory going back, but we don't even see much in the way of DN3D's "do you want to take the left or the right air vent / the vent or the regular corridor to get to the same place" kind of thing that doesn't slow the game down. On the upside this doesn't just go for maps, but for the plot as well: this means no side-quests (on which I've OD'd a bit), and the main plot uses that thing very sparingly where you're trying to do something, then it turns out you'll have to achieve a prerequisite first, then while trying to do that, you'll end up with a prerequisite for the prerequisite, et cetera ad nauseam, and instead of achieving objectives, you have a stack of half-finished objectives ten deep. So yeah, Singularity mostly avoids that, doesn't stack objectives too deeply when it stacks them, and the objectives they give you tend to feel justified rather than forced or an interruption.- This is a 2010 game, so the graphics are mildly dated, but I found them fit for purpose. I have no regrets. Your mileage may vary. On the plus side, even though the game is mildly scary in the beginning (it's night, you have no or no good weapons, and you don't know what you're up against -- or worse, you've found out what you're up against, but still don't have anything decent to defend yourself with), it never stoops to the whole "It's scary only because you can't see♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; level. (If I never have to see a flashlight again, especially one that only illuminates 1/8 of the screen, it'll be too soon. If I pay for a whole game, 1/8 won't do.)- No Steam achievements. :( This is particularly sad as the console versions are said to have achievements/trophies.- I started this instead of surfing when my net went down. Game would freeze for a second every few seconds until net came back, not sure whether "always online" requirement, or initial activation, or what. Research this if that sort of thing is incompatible with your setup or principles.- I wouldn't have minded the option of a female avatar. Seeing as we're pretty much dealing with a mute protagonist here, it's not like it would've incurred much extra cost for voice work. In fact as we pretty much never see our avatar, it may not matter much, but then as we pretty much never see our avatar, it would've been all the easier to implement, simply by not making references at all and just calling you Captain, Renko, or a combination thereof.- There's multi-player (which I haven't tried), but no co-op.- No proper saves ("When you want, where you want, however many you want"). Game auto-saves fairly often so even if things go wrong, you rarely lose much progress, but obviously this way, you can't replay "just that bit you really liked" or show your friend "that super cool scene" to get them to buy the game too, so as in all other games with that defect, the developers are idiots for limiting replay value and word of mouth.VERDICTVery solid single player experience; hard to beat at current price point. If linearity doesn't put you off gameplay wise, or the lack of proper saves, female avatars, and possibly an always-on requirement doesn't politics-wise, go for it!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												Singularity is a visually engaging fps that does not try anything new.  The game is a good length, has a solid story, a hand-full of strong characters and a nice variety of combat.  The game undoubtedly feels like a side project but a finished one!  It  might not have the detail and love that one would expect in a CoD game, but I was impressed with Activision's ability to begin and end a story with the time that was given.The game takes many ques from other games.  While Singularity might not bring anything new to the table, it does bring a well blended action fps for any gamer to enjoy.  Nothing is taken too far with this game.  There is a good number of different enemy types, but not so many that the player isn't able to learn how to combat them before the game is over.  Also, there are at least ten weapons to choose from -- most of which can be upgraded and changed out at weapon stations.The "TMD" device that the player is given adds a shocking amount of combat options.  The different uses of weapons and "TMD" abilities with the added upgrading and leveling system could make for another good play-though -- maybe two.  Unfortunately, the fights are scripted, and that takes a bit from the replays.Over all, the game gets a good review because it feels "humble."  It isn't a ground breaking or epic title, and it does not try to be.  The game gives the player a gripping intro, good progression and good old fashioned boss fights!  Note: $30 would have been spot on the day this game came out.  Best bought on sale now.


Singularity 
A Screenshot of Singularity

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												While the multiplayer aspect of this game is sadly extinct, Singularity thankfully still exists as one rare gem: As the greatest lovestory between two men ever told, without pandering to the usual cliches seen in representations of homosexual men in the media.Thats right. Singularity is the best, to date, representation of homosexual romance in a FPS.Are the pseudo-RPG elements gimicky? Yes. Is the story only slighty more existant than that found in the 'Metro' series? Yes. Is the 3-optional ending choice rather pointless? Also yes.But the tragic romance between our pseudo-silent protagnoist and James Devlin is truly one to be witnessed. A romance that, though as I stated IS tragic, is truly and literally timeless. You must simply experience it for yourself to understand.All provided with the soothing and not-overused-at-all voices of Nolan North and Steve Blum. Play it, and witness this tasteful homosexual romance story of loss and grief for yourself.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Although short, this game is worth a play through. The story doesn't offer too much to say "wow" about, but the way the developers played with time is pretty interesting and offers for some interesting game play mechanics. This is not to say they are mechanics that have never been seen before, but they do offer interesting puzzles and fun methods of fighting the baddies. Controls are decent, the art was decent for the time, and enemies can be somewhat challenging; that is not to say the game is incredibly hard - it won't be terribly difficult to beat if you have much experience with shooters.Alternate history is always fun, and the fact that this game centers around Cold War-era environs and shies away from the typical WWII trope that had become commonplace makes this game well worth at least one play.I can't say that it will warrant a second run through as once you've uncovered all the "twists" the game offers, there isn't much to go back to.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												The last original IP from Raven Software, Singularity is a Bioshock meets Metro FPS. As a few games released around 2010, it's a troubled PC port, it takes a few tweaks to the registry to make it running at higher resolutions and it needs Widescreen Fixer to adjust the FOV, but the texture streaming bug still persist (you need to restart the game every hour or so) . Although a few guns lack weight it is a pretty entertainment 6 hour game, with upgradable guns and skills and old school medkit health system.PS: Multiplayer can still be played i believe (could not find 6 people to play with).

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Have yet to finish it, but if you can get this for $10 or less it's a great buy.  First 5 minuites feel like call of duty until it slowly turns into something way more unique.Edit after finishing:Deffinitly worth $10, gameplay is pretty good, graphics are good for it's time (somewhat better than mw1), with a futuristic yet old style you usually only see in games like fallout 3.  Gameplay is mostly the standard shooter, but very satisfying, and has a number of gadgets and gameplay mechanics, playing with time, that you don't normally see.There's  definitly some challenge to be had, it's probably an 8 hour game if you rush through it on easy though.  There are multiple endings, but not very much in the way of player choice (Still more than bioshock infinite).  The weapons are nice, and feel great, though gun specific upgrades are limited to damage, reload speed, and clip size.  You can uprade other charecter stats, though most of the good upgrades come too late in the game to be all that useful.

												Awesome linear cooridor shooter where you use a gun that warps and uses time to your advantage. Great game to power through on a weekend! PROS:Story is interesting and fun in an 80's movie wayOne of the coolest weapons since the Gravity Gun7-8 hours of gameplay that never really slows downGood selection of weapons to use that all feel good in their own wayCONS:Reeks of late 2000's shooter (Kicking doors to shoot baddies in slow motion, equiping 2 weapons only, the only color is BROWN) No subtitlesStupid easy half way through after a few powerupsI highly recommend Singularity if it somehow missed your radar if you liked games like Half-life 2, Bioshock, Timeshift, Doom 3, F.E.A.R., and Resistance.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												Excellent shooter. Highly recommendSet in a "somewhat postapocalyptic" soviet environment this is a classic First person shooter with some "super-powers" added besides the usual guns. Gameplay is reminiscent of Bioshock, while the setting and atmosphere are close to Metro 2033.You play as an american soldier sent to investigate closed down and abandoned Soviet facility, where you uncover mistery E99 element and events follow.What I really liked about the game:-The gameplay is very solid. You have good amount of different, well-designed weapons (the game keeps giving you new ones right until the end, that way it keeps things interesting). Also you have some superpowers (not from beginning but quite early into the game you get your first one) and the list of the things you can do grows. Timeshift bubble, aging opponents, impulsing all around you, telekinesis. All that good stuff. Overall, the shooting part is fun and makes you feel like a bad♥♥♥♥♥ The 'puzzles' won't take -The setting. Very gruesome, graphic. Reminiscent of Metro but more "paranormal" stuff.What is not particularly great but holds up:-The story. It's pretty linear and straightforward for a game about time-travel and altering history/future, but still it is enjoyable and grips you until the end. The game even has 3 endings, but they are basically the same, just different cut-scenes in the end and you can replay last 1 minute of the game to see them all.What I disliked:-For a game that's been out for like 2 years already there's too many bugs. I've had to restart the game around 5 times due to game-breaking bugs (NPCs stuck or disappearing, doors not opening e.t.c) and the thing is - I've wasted good amount of time in each of those instances to figure out that something is wrong. Once there was a sequence where a girl opened some door and I needed to defend her from monsters. Well, the thing got stuck and the monsters spawned endlessly and I couldn't undestand that something is wrong until I wasted all my bullets, medkits, e99 energy and they just killed me (I wasted around 10-15 minutes I think) and after restart the process ended in like 3 monsters and 15 seconds.All in all, solid title. Recommend to play it if you like shooters, enjoyed Metro 2033 and/or Bioshock.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												While there are not a lot of new mechanics that Singularity offers, they do hit all of the FPS checkboxes. The levels are linear but well planned and with enough hidden goodies that it is worth seeing them. Most of those hidden goodies are E99, the main currency of the game and the major plot device of it too. The human enemies have a decent enough A.I. and the non-human enemies tend to rush you like a giant bullet sponge. The weapons are all the general FPS weapons; pistol, shotgun, rifle, sniper rifle, and rocket launcher are all there. There is one weapon, the Seeker, that allows you to control the flight path of the bullet while slowing down time. Like the killshots in the game Nazi Zombie Army, the Seeker lets you lay out a plan of attack. The Seeker is also the closest you'll come to actually controlling time. The device used to control time feels underwhelming and pigeon-holed into a few uses. It eventually has two upgradeable powers, the ability to send out a pulse to hurt and push back enemies and a time bubble that greatly slows down anything caught in it that isn't you. For the bubble your bullets will go slow and so will enemy fire, but it will still be moving and able to cause damage. Exploding barrels (I mentioned this game hit all the FPS benchmarks didn't I?) don't explode until after the effect of the time bubble has ended. The pulse is essentially useless, even when at the end <spoilers> the device becomes "uber" and can rip off the limbs of unarmed enemies, the actual distance the pulse reaches is so small unless something is right next to you, it won't help.However the game has a great amount of detail and production and is similar to Bioshock both in style and mechanics so I do recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												Worthy.  Combination of the gravity gun of HL2 and the repair ability from Red Faction Armageddon.  Some nice shooter puzzles and decent combat.  Classic tension between guns (two at a time, limited ammo) plus some personal and weapon upgrades.  Good rewards for exploration!  (One hint on that:  Do press the "glowing footsteps" button to figure out which direction is forward:  The path behind you quietly closes often, and without warning, when you're moving "forward.")

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
 Singularity™ This is one of these, for today’s standards, uncommon Single player Shooter jewels, that`re not exploited too hell and back with sequels and micro transactions. Surely the Graphics are dated and it’s not flawless. But I like a good Story Shooter. And that’s what it does, no more, no less. It’s an interesting Story where I wanted to see what happened next. Interesting premise, not so cliché and 08/15. Gunplay is good, Framerate stable and no weird glitches or bugs. Abilities are good, pacing nice. And one thing so much shooter do wrong: At the higher difficulty levels, you don`t get simply insta Headshots (Yeah, I look at you Homefront). No the enemies simply do more damage and you have less health. Ammo and Pickups are fewer and far between. That’s how you do a higher Difficulty in a Shooter.Pro:good Weapon feelnicely pacedgreat uncommon StoryLevel Designnice enemy’s Design and varietyContra:Graphics now Datedvery linearReally Solid Shooter with a very good alternate Timeline Story and multiple Endings. Don`t find these often these times.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2011
												Beautiful graphics, great storyline, and a fun gameplay mechanic.Singularity is a hidden gem that sadly doesn't shine bright enough to be a 10 out of 10 game, but is a great one nonetheless.The game revolves around the Time Manipulation Device, or T.M.D. which one uses to travel between 2 eras in the same areas in the game. Depending on which time zone you're in, different things happen.The voice acting is pretty nice, and the graphics are phenomenal for a game of it's time.The storyline, while interesting isn't anything special, sadly, but is still well-written.The game provides several hours of fun and 2 ways to play the game based on your preference for the T.M.D. and manipulation of enemies or just a run-and-gun style.Overall it's a pretty fun game and a recommended buy, but maybe for $10, not $20 or $30.

												A short game, but definitely a good one. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												I decided to pick this up at a steam sale but as a huge sci-fi fan I knew just how many ways there to mess up a time travel based storyline. singularity was amaizing well done. the game play mechanics really force you to rely on the time dilation because your health goes down alot faster than most shooters and the medkits are common but if you try to use one in combat youll be dead by the time you finish the healing animations. over all i would say it is a challanging game that surprising gets a bit easier later on due to the upgrades but you always need to be on your toes. as for the story line its quite imaginative however can be cliche at times. although you really need to look for all the notes and audio recorders to get the full details. One thing that really made me impresed and I Wont give any specific spoilers, but to date its the only game i have ever played that doesent have the player killed betrayed, or arbitrarally punished by karma for choosing the evil ending }:)>

												I just picked this game up for $7.49 during this weekends Activision sale. It's just your average, run of the mill first person shooter, but I like it.My thoughts:- Graphics are good enough for me- Controls are mappable ( Mapped my controller like Halo)- Story is ok so far- Voice acting is good- Should have added grenades of some sort- Runs nice on low powered machine- So far full controller supportOne small quirk is that the 'Use' & 'Reload' actions are mapped to the one button. I love roaming in games... I try to  open every door. So when I check a door that is just scenery, it reloads my weapon instead... I keep running out of bullets.... Like I said this is a minor quirk.The movie projector films are funny to watch.

content:

												This is a hidden score in a vast trove of Sci-Fi shooters that flood the market. It takes elements from all the greats (Half-Life, Bioshock, even the eerie scenery of STALKER games) and brings an amusing twist of time travel, Russian banter, and an all around good story. I thoroughly enjoyed this game for all it was worth. Do yourself a favor and pick this up when you can, you're bound to enjoy it.P.S. As with all games, be sure to check out all the little things added into the game for your enjoyment. Explore. Dig through desks & lockers. There's lots to uncover in this ridulous world.

												I had been wanting to purchase this game for a while after reading that it was somewhat like the first Bioshock. Finally catching it on sale for 7 dollars I grabed it and wow. This game is amazing, flew straight under my radar. It's not much at all like Bioshock imo but its a fantastic scfy shooter/action game. The story is amazing, combat is fun and challengeing. The game borrors from many other games and combines it into one fresh idea that is a ton of fun. The game is just fantastic for 7.50 but after playing it  now I would have gladly paid retail for this game. If you're into science fiction universes, like aliens, old war settings with experiments gone wrong, enjoy shooters mixed with rpg elements, upgrade systems, and various other elements, and most importantly love a good story then purchase this game! Easily 9/10 for me and I'm not even half way through yet.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												So, you have played all the 'big' FPS titles around, looking for something else to play and you want a reccomendation.. get Singularity.  I have played through this on both 360 and PS3 before picking it up on PC, it is one of the few games that truely deserve the title of 'hidden gem'.  So whats it like?  Well, its a sci-fi FPS, along the same lines as half-life and with just as much interesting cool puzzles and lore.  Furthermore, the story is great, which is unusual for a FPS.  It would hold its own with the classics such as Bioshock.  I won't go into too much detail but it involves time travel and it is quite well thought out, sure like every time travel escapade in recent memory it has slight plot holes but hey your carrying huge guns and blowing things apart on every turn.An added extra is the atmosphere, its a well thoughtout game and the setting is amazing, especially when things get changed by time and you see the same environment but from a different era.All in all, if you want a romp-gun fest.. get this game.. if you want a cool sci-fi adventure... get this game.. if you want a game you can highly reccomend to your friends and feel good when they also love it.. get this game.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												Surprisingly good. Although you breeze through it in 5 hours and it's not very hard (unbalanced even - if you use the time slowdown sphere and some tmp upgrades you can just run through most parts). It starts off quite weak but once you get a hold of the TMP it gets really good. The story is rather straightforward but I have to say that I really enjoyed it and it was refreshing to play a linear FPS that was this entertaining.Singularity really resembles half life in quite a few ways and it is really good in teaching you the mechanics. The controls are also really intuitive/good (except the default bind for healing)my issues:One note on mechanical side - I lost a lot of E99 money because in tmp you actually have to equip something to the slot. I missed that and treated it as other upgrades so I had a ton of upgrades for tmp that did not work and I spent the currency for.The lore is expanded via notes and tapes but there could be more of the "show, don't tell" visual narrative.Overall it seemed like there was more potential than what the game showed and the puzzles could include more variations (i,e, you need to use the grenade launcher exactly once and then forget about it, modifying time in later sections is mostly used for opening boxes and restoring tape recorders compared to strong first half where it was used for various objects, turning soldiers into husks was fun but rather inefficient shortly after it was introduced etc).

												Excellent, atmospheric FPS. The beginning of the game is delightfully spooky and a slow burn. You're given time to explore for a bit, without a weapon, building dread and expectation. It could pass for a first-rate horror game for the first twenty minutes. It thing segues into more predictable shooter territority, but the shooting is quite solid and the plot interesting enough to keep you moving forward. The time manipulation powers are a lot of fun if you take the time to learn when best to employ them. Lots of audiologs to find as well. Highly recommended for any FPS fan who is more interested in atmosphere than mowing down waves of enemies.

												I am always a sucker for time-manipulation games, and this one did not disappoint me. I was a huge fan of TimeShift, a game you should also check out if time control is something you are interested in. The wrist device mechanic was very fun and I liked being shifted back and forth between pre and post-disaster time periods. It was like switching between a horror and a general action atmosphere. You get used to just fighting baddies with guns, and then suddenly you are thrown back into the island after everything went to crap, and you have to remember that terrible things can pop out at you again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Singularity is probably the most underrated game I have ever played, and it is, among other things; the most atmospheric game I've ever experienced.I first bought Singularity on the Xbox when it first came out, played it about halfway and loved it, but then my Xbox broke and I couldn't continue the journey. Ever since then I've longed to get back to the game and finish it. As time progressed though, I started to think to myself that the game wasn't that great, and I was just imagining it as some sort of contender Half-Life 2; the singleplayer FPS king. Fast forward to present time, when I found it on sale and instantly bought it, eager to relive the memories. I was ready to get dissapointed and my expectations were actually quite low, but as soon as I booted it up I realized that I hadn't imagined anything; the game is just as incredible as I remembered.You start the game in the boots of Nathaniel Renko, Captain in the U.S. military, on a mission to the remote island of 'Kartorga 12', which, in the 1950's, had been home to various scientific experiments conducted by the Soviet Union. After a terrible crash due to some unexplainable explosion, you quickly realize that said experiments hadn't really gone according to plan and 'Katorga 12' wasn't quite the Soviet Utopia it was advertised to be in the 50's...What follows is an incredible journey with amazing looking vistas, interesting characters and mechanics that, to this day, feel fresh. A game that rivals games like Half-Life 2 and Bioshock in atmospheric, story driven FPS's. It might not have the utmost polish, like HL2, but nothing that gets in the way of what this game does best; atmosphere.Techinically, compared to new games (i.e. BF4, Crysis 3) the game might look a little bit dated (in 2014), but the graphical design makes the game still look incredible, with some of my most memorable locations in video gaming.As far as sound design goes, the developers has worked wonders, the score is just right and every weapon sounds just like you want them to; powerful and distinctful. If there is something to complain about it's that the voice acting can, on some lines be, a bit cringe-y, but for the most part it does the job well and even the Russian accents sound believable for the most part.Even though is game is several years old, the mechanics used still feel fresh and like something new. Without spoilering, you can manipulate the environment to quite a big degree which keeps the combat feeling fresh and it ties in very, very nicely with the story and story telling.In the end; if you're a fan of story driven games, don't mind a good FPS or enjoy post apocalyptic stories like Fallout or Metro 2033/Last Light, you should definately give Singularity a chance. It might be a couple of years old, but it still holds up very well and is one of the most underated games ever made.WARNING: The PC port is unfortunately absolutely♥♥♥♥♥♥though. BUT, it is fixable, at least to a degree. The game runs fine at my system (AMD FX-8350 4,0GHz, AMD R9 290, 8GB RAM) with over 60 frames per second during the whole game at 1920x1080p, with everything on. There are not many graphical options to speak of tough, so it might not be tailorable to your computer, if you're running a lower end rig.The FOV was the biggest problem for me though, with it being locked to console FOV (~60). This is however semi-fixable with a great program called "Flawless Widescreen". Be warned though, increasing the FOV causes the playable characters arms to clip, making you be able to see thru them at the bottom of your screen while using some weapons and during some events. It is very slight and to me, it's not a very big deal, but to some people it might be immersion breaking, so; you have been warned.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												Well what can I say? It was pretty to look at, the story intrigued me, and the zombies made me jump on two occaisons. However, it lacks a quick save function, which prevented me from completing the game. Now I'm no save ♥♥♥♥♥♥, I don't need to save every five seconds because I'm prone to dying - no, I need to save when I feel things are about to get serious because it's very possible I've missed something and would like the chance to go back if it turns out I have. Basically I found myself with next to nothing ammo in a colourful room full of teleporting zombies. My knife is made of plastic, I have 3 bullets on my pistol and about 12 bullets on my rifle. There's no ammo anywhere, and the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game wants you to kill your 6 ( i think) attackers. After doing some digging, it turns out I walked right past a refill point. My fault for not seeing it, but the game has locked me out of that area so now it's pretty much saying "Your fault for looking at the pretty scenery and not the glowing box thing a second ago, sucks brah". My only option? To replay.This game is not good enough to earn a replay. The frustration factor vs the OH WOW factor is just too one sided for that. It's probably a good game, and I did enjoy it until the mishap, so I would recomend it to someone who wants to kill the time. Maybe I'll revisit at some point. Probably not.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												I wanted to play a game in which I shoot stuff. I also prefer my shooting games to have something quirky or fun or special to set them apart from all the other shooting games. I bought Singularity and it delivered, for the most part, at least.Singularity is a very basic shooter. It's story is nothing really special (it's a very predictable time-traveling mess), the voice acting is standard, the guns are regular guns (except for the seeker, which the game occasionally hands you so you can have some fun) and the enemies are russians who shoot you and mutants that slash, punch and bite you.So what sets this game apart?The TIME MANIPULATION DEVICE! While the game occasionally seems to forget that the thing exists, and while the mechanics on which it operates (story-wise) are confusing as hell and while it's mostly just a gravity gun with a "kill enemy" function, it DOES set Singularity apart from all the other shooters. An enemy giving you trouble? Age him/it to dust! A bunch of soldiers giving you trouble? Revert a couple of them into feral mutants and watch the madness. The TMD also allows for some fun puzzle design, which is a bonus as far as I am concerned.Singularity is not a long game and it's not the best game there is, but it's competent and well worth a few bucks and an evening or two.Playtime: 5+ hours (single playthrough)Ratings (1-10)Visual: 7Audio: 7Story: 5Gameplay: 8Overall: 7

content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												Singularity is a quality, fairly short blast of silliness. It aspires to be comparable to 'Bioshock', a worthy aim that it comes admirably close to fulfilling. Although Gamespot said that the game's visuals were a little lacking (their overall review was positive, giving it 8/10, and a 'Great') I thought the environments were pretty awesome. Highlights for me were when you saw a location in the present, only to be flung back in time 50 years, to see the same place in all its shiny freshness. I was surprised that they didn't actually do this more often in the game really. Another iteration of this visual effect was walking though a ship where sudden time-pulses would age it, as you stumbled onward. A wall of rust and corrosion would move like a wave over every surface, an original and interesting idea. Furthermore, the gunplay of the game was slick and satisfying, suffering from none of the 'sludginess' that some FPS's can have. Comparisons to that of 'Bioshock' are again tempting - the enemy body physics, the art design of the guns, the damage effects of your weapons: all were oddly similar. But there were more obvious similarities. For example, the character enhancement and gun customization elements seemed like brazen copies (perhaps I should say 'respectful homages'?) to the 'Bioshock' franchise. The 'secondary weapon' in your other hand (here, the so-called Time Manipulation Device, Singularity's answer to Plasmids) was identical! While these elements worked well, they were all ultimately a little limited because the game is so much shorter. As regards developing a credible 'alternative world' and engaging in deeper philosophical questions, Singularity only dabbled the fingers of its TMD-adorned-hand ever so slightly in these areas. Ultimately the game puts playability and humour first - think Red Alert crossed between Metro 2033, and you're warm - and there is never any shame in that.  It's a short game - even if you're a thorough completionist, like me, it will still all be over in about 10 hours - but the price reflects this. The game offers a fun, silly and satisfying ride. There's no doubt that a Time Manipulation Device would be useful in reclaiming all those wasted hours frittered away on medicore games, but here at least it's time well spent!

content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												Singularity is a pretty solid FPS game, though it's not worth its asking price. If you can get it at 75% off, then it is well worth your money.To me, Singularity feels like a blend of ideas and influences from other FPS games, but it is done very well, and the end product does feel like a game of it's own, and it makes this multiple directions work well.You play as a US soldier sent to investigate an energy surge on an island off the coast of Russia where secret experiments were performed with the fictional mineral E-99, until a massive explosion destroyed the island in the 50's. Once there, another energy surge sends you to the past, and once you return, you realize that you changed the present and that Russia rules the world. From there on, you try to fix the present by once again changing the past.The story wants to be complex, but ends up being relatively simple and kind of falls flat, with the twist not really being a twist(and can easily be deduced 5 minutes into the game), which is revealed a moment before the final decision which leads to 3 different endings which all felt rushed and cobbled together, and none felt like a satisfactory end to the story. Still, I did enjoy it most of the time, especially when it hinted at something more intruging that the straightforward route it ended up taking.Graphically and visually, the game felt a lot like Bioshock to me. It doesn't resemble the environments of Bioshock, but the overall atmosphere of you in a place where something bad happened prior to your arrival and the way it uses environmental storytelling with audio recordings, notes, and movies you can find felt a lot like how I explored Rapture. The HUD is almost a direct copy of Bioshock's, the best way to describe it would be to call it "Bioshock with a slightly different skin". The island design is pretty good, and I enjoyed exploring it for upgrade materials almost just as much as I did in Rapture.Also the game frequently sends you back in time, so you get to explore the environments both now and in the 50's before the xplosion, similar to the principle used in Prince of Persia Warrior Within.In terms of gameplay, this is where the game shines, and again, feels a lot like Bioshock, with a pinch of FEAR in the mix. You have a decent arsenal of guns, all of which can be upgraded with tech found on the way. You can also upgrade yourself, gaining increased health and other perks, some of which are very unbalanced and can potential break the game flow. You can carry two guns at a time, and can pick up weapons and ammo from fallen enemies, as well as change your loadout at predestined locations. Some weapons offer you the ability to slow-down time while you aim, though this does not last long and has to recharge before being used again.You are also given a TMD(time manipulation device) which grants you a small array of time powers used to solve simple, yet clever puzzles and aid you in combat. You can age your opponents to dust, freeze everything in an area, or create a large energy pulse to knock them back. Also, the TMD has all the capabilites of Half-Life 2's gravity gun, allowing you to throw explosive barrels at enemies or catch their grenades mid-air and return them.The gunplay feels great, and the powers add enough variety to keep things interesting as you gun down russian soldiers and various mutants, though there were some enemy types which were really annoying, which is the only issue I have with the gameplay.Overall, the game is relatively short, lasting about 3-5 hours depending on you speed, but very enjoyable experience. I do feel they could have done a little more with the game, especially in terms of the story and it rushed ending, but still, I would recommend buying the game if you can get it at a discount.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												Singularity held up pretty well as an old-school shooter that has no cover-shoot, and no autoheal. What it does have is the TMD, a time manipulation device that you can deploy both in combat and merely to solve environmental puzzles. The setup is pretty cute... a major radiation event on an abandoned island near the Russian border lead to a special US response... a spec ops team moved in, but an EMP event have them crashed on the island and the team scattered. You, Renko, must traverse the island, attempt to reunite with your teammates, and figure out what's wrong with this island, as the singularity whipsaws you between 2010 (game's "present day") and 1955. You screwed up history in one of those whipsaw transitions, and you have to spend rest of the game trying to undo what you have done, as you fight your way through soldiers (both 1955 and 2010) and monsters, horribly mutated humans and whatelse left on the island also horribly mutated. What really sets the game apart is how your special power, the TMD, can be deployed in combat. There's a "shockwave" command that blasts all enemies back, and by endgame it is upgraded to limb shedding slam power. Enemies that phase shift (blinks in and out) can be "blasted" by the shockwave back to the present for you to shoot. The device is also a personal tractor beam for grabbing and throwing. Grab an explosive barrel (either on the ground or in midair, such as one thrown at you), and throw it at the enemy.  Many objects can be aged (turned into ruined version) or deaged (return to pristine condition). You will end up de-aging a lot of things. Busted boxes that contain medkits and ammo can be deaged. Regular boxes can be aged so they can fit through gaps that they would not otherwise fit, like under a door, then de-aged so it acts as a jack to lift the door up, or use as a platform for you to jump onto other places. Enemies can be aged, safes can be aged (technically, just the safe door). The TMD can also throw a protective bubble shield to freeze time for a few seconds. The game offers various upgrades for your TMD and your weapons, and there are a nice selection if a bit typical: pistol, shotgun, assault rifle, then it veered into the exotic, like a grenade launcher that alternately launches a guided "rolling ball", a spike launcher that launches explosive spikes, a sniper rifle with time-dilation (i.e. bullet time) when scoped, and the autocannon (a gatling gun, actually). You can discover "weapon tech" points that you can spend on upgrades (each weapon can be upgraded in reload speed, clip capacity, or raw damage) during your travels. You can also accumulate "E99" energy containers that acts as currency that you can spend on additional TMD upgrades (betware as you can only equip one TMD upgrade at a time), as well as other perks like "better projectile damage resistance", or "recharge health per kill".  You can access those at the various TMD upgrade stations and Weapon Stations. Combat is pretty frantic as the game throws new challenges at you all the time, and some of the environment puzzles are genius. If you are stuck on where to go, there's always "chrono-ping" which tells you which way you should go. The game involves time travel, so it should be no surprise that there are plenty of causuality loops, and there's a big reveal near the end that sets up for a sequel, which has yet to happen, but a tweet earlier in 2015 seem to suggest that the developer is working on such. And there are at least three endings (and two fail-repeat semi-endings) that you can attempt to get. The graphics are quite good (you almost can't tell it's a 2010 game) and sound effects very well done (proper stereo effects as you turn the character around and the sound source does localize). Music tempo increases with combat and ends when all enemies are defeated. All in all, Singularity is one of those games that few people have played, as it's so oldschool, but it plays fine today, which is a lot of praise for a 5 year old game (released 2010, reviewed 2015).

												Amazing experience and a totally overlooked gem. So much fun, inventive, deliciously sadistic weapons. Totally linear, but a good story, great set pieces. Well-designed levels never get too frustrating, it's never samey because the art direction keeps the visuals fresh. Boss fights are epic. Honestly, I enjoyed it more than Bioshock. I don't think it's as well-developed as a world and characters, but I'm talking about pure entertainment value. Graphics aside, it doesn't feel particularly aged. Most current FPS games are no better, just a little prettier.Only annoying thing is, when using a gamepad, the buttons aren't shown in on-screen prompts, only keyboard keys. An oversight which will never be remedied now, but it hardly ruins the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Singularity is one of those hidden gems that seem to only attract its real fans long after its demise and relegation to the scrap heap. Don't misunderstand that as the game being bad, because it most certainly is not. Singularity is everything that used to be fun in the FPS genre, before mainstreaming took it over. Essentially, Singularity is a popcorn shooter with fluid non-stop combat, lots of enemies, a great story, a lengthy singleplayer campaign and a neat RPG-lite character building system that borrows from System Shock/Bioshock without completely ripping them off.Your average shooter fan won't like Singularity since it speaks more to the 90s gamers out there, so be warned if you're expecting something modern. That being said, If you want a solid FPS with a clever gimmick, an entertaining story and some great level design....here you go. Thank me later.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Singularity is a really awesome game, which you could compare the most to FEAR in my opinion. It has a creepy atmosphere at the start and although the game focusses more on action overall it still has a dark and threatening atmopshere in some levels. Additional to that you also find notes and audiotapes throughout the game, which provides you with background information about Katorga 12.The developers made a good job to keep that time travel theme in your mind. During your journey you will see visions of former citizens of the island how they talked to eacxh other or you see the scene of their death.The gameplay itself is pretty fun and besides the standard shooter weapons there are also some sci-fi guns like the Seeker, which allows you to control your bullets after a shot. The Singularity powers are also fun to use. I have to agree that there are not much of them, which gets compensated by the fact that every enemy reacts different to your aging ability and the "time sphere" can be used in an agressive or defensive way. In short I can say if you liked Bioshock and FEAR I think you will have fun with this game as well. And if you are concerned about the time in which Singualirty play you don't need to worry. The game is set in 2010, but you also make some short trips to 1955 and fight WW 2 Soviets.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Katorga-12. Nevar 4get ;_;In all honesty though, this is a "Hidden Gem" game if ever I've played one. A great selection of unique and fun weapons that all have weight to them (dat sniper rifle), a great gore/gib system, frantic combat with competent AI, a half way decent story, and unique time bending abilites that give you the edge you need in combat. Words can't describe how fun it is to put a squad of 4 or more enemies into a stasis bubble, walking into the bubble, taking aim and firing a bullet right between each enemies eyes, then collapsing the bubble and watching all 4 mean go flying backwards as their brains leak out the back of their foreheads. Or dropping a grenade at their feet and watching them explode inside the stasis bubble in super slow motion. Good times. And in the end game, when you get your final upgrade, you're literally a god amongst men. This game represents what Activision COULD have given us- fun, unique, and well designed shooters, that encouraged fun over realism, weapons that all had unique functions instead of "This rifle shoots really fast, this one shoots in 3 round bursts, and this one fire slowly but deal lots of damage." Instead we're stuck with a new Cawwa Doody every year. Our sins our great, and we gotta carry that weight. No amount of rewinding time will fix this now.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Fantastic game, despite its age. There's nothing quite like anihilating a room full of soldies with a sniper rifle that lets you steer bullets.The game has a really creepy atmosphere. Dried out corpses are all over the place, and once in a while you get a time shift into back when they were still alive and see their suffering. You fight against monsters who used to be humans but got messed up by time radiation. You also fight against modern day soldiers. You also fight against 1950s soldiers.You have a TMD, a special device that lets you age things (or soldiers) or revert old things back to new, among other things, like shooting time-slowing bubbles. There are quite a few "puzzles" where you have to think how to age or unage containers and power boxes, among other things, to get further.The story... I wasn't really following it. It felt like some scientist was just telling me what to do (similar to Half-Life) and I just trudged along. I kept thinking he was about to screw me over the entire time. But the impact of what a time-altering technology in the wrong hands can do is tangible throughout the game.So if you can handle feeling the dread of inexorable death waiting for you around the corner as you watch things decay, this game is for you!P.S.: the game is ancient, so for obvious reasons the multiplayer is dead. You can't even start it up and wonder around the map alone.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												Singularity takes different video games ideas, it's undeniable! (Doom 3, Half-life 1&2, Dead Space series, Portal, Return to Castle Wolfenstein (RTCW), and more). The good thing is that the Scenario is good. Not great, but good. The ambiance is interesting also. Some people would say that this game is way under-rated, I would say no because it is linear, there is some repetitive actions, you can't go where you want because of tons of boring invisible walls, but at least you can find some secret areas and there is many predictable situations.I recommand you Singularity if you are a fan of FPS's in general! But now, if this game is one of the greatest FPS ever? Of course not, but at least it is very interesting and entertaining! So yes, you can purchase it now!Singularity is based on Epic Games - Unreal Engine 3.  Graphics / Mapping: 7/10  - Invisible walls and some ugly and blurry textures! Action / Scenario: 7/10  - A little bit of deja vu. Musics / Sound: 5/10  - Good... but not great. Programing: 9/10  - Why 9? Because I prefer ID Software 3D engines for many reasons but Unreal Engine is amazing too.

												Нельзя никак менять прошлое, ибо это может привести к непредсказуемым последствиям. Чему нас, собственно, и учит Singularity. В результате лишь одного действия заброшенный островок в Охотском море становится источником энергии, достаточной для захвата мира. И только один человек - капитан Натаниель Ренко может предотвратить катастрофу в прошлом, потому что все нити сюжета указывают именно на него. Человека, который и сам хотел бы распутать этот клубок тайн и узнать, почему только он может всех спасти.От себя лишь хочется добавить, что это добротный, но немного подзабытый шутер, в котором все аспекты работают, геймплей держит до самого конца, подкреплённый неплохой графикой.И, хотя до содержания финальных твистов можно дойти и самому, концовка не разочарует.P.S. И да, в игре нет хэппи-энда, даже несмотря на то, что концовки три. Потому что у этой истории просто не может быть хорошего конца.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												Of course, you already know what Singularity is like: it's like a hundred other games. You slow down time. You freeze time. You have a highly advanced piece of kit that allows you to break things and repair them again (not a spanner). Press a different button and you can lift things, use them as shields and throw them at bad people. Did you say Gravity Gun?Graphics are courtesy of Unreal 3 for the last console gen, which means bad. Hardly any detail and lo-res shaders like everything is smeared with vaseline. There are no settings to turn up. The plot is also gibberish. You go forward in time, you go back in time. You shoot a man in the head then he starts having a conversation about causality, so you have to shoot him again. It's almost as bad as Bioshock Infinite. Almost. Still, the big spiders were nice, the guns were alright and it was £2.50, so that's a thumbs up. 5/10.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												Singularity had the potential to be something truly great. A promising concept (time manipulation) combined with an interesting sci-fi plot, Singularity instead doesn't use its chosen gimmick to its fullest, relegating it to mild puzzle solving (with some occasional gigantic logic holes - why can't I just climb over this collapsed door instead of crawling through yet more sewer pipe to get to the same place?) and some moderately useful combat abilities, most of which can only be used a handful of times per engagement; I ended up forgetting I had them. In addition, the game has only one proper boss fight and basically gives you God Mode near the end, making the difficulty not so much peak as plunge. You can get through practically the entire game with the assault rifle and the shotgun (the game conveniently provides a nearby sniper rifle whenever the situation calls for it).That's not to say Singularity is a bad game. It isn't. The shooting feels tight and the ability to upgrade the damage, capacity, and reload times of your weapons is neat. It just could have been so, so much better if they had used their tools more effectively, given us more to do with the time manipulation mechanic, and hadn't tried to crowbar in some Bioshock-esque "twists" near the end. Missed opportunities, but still worth getting on sale.7/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												Singularity is a First-Person Shooter made by Raven Software, it is designed in a similar vein to games like the Bioshock series.. There's very light RPG elements, and a fair amount of story, much of which is told through audiologs spread throughout the world.Gameplay wise, Singularity plays like most modern FPS titles, with a few minor exceptions. For the most part, you'll only be able to carry two weapons. On the otherhand, outside of some of the upgrades you can buy, there's no regenerating health, meaning you'll have be on the lookout for health packs throughout the world. The level design consists of your fairly standard corridors with enemies with the occasional larger arena designed for combat. The game decently rewards exploration, with E99 Tech (the games currency for upgrading weapons/your character), health packs and ammo and audiologs. Asides from the standard running and gunning, you'll also find yourself solving a puzzle every so often, those these are mostly straight-forward, and shouldn't cause much trouble. From a gameplay standpont, the big gimmick is the TMD, or the time manipulation device. As you might guess, it is a device that allows you to maniuplate time in a multitude of ways. The main ability of the TMD is being able to age certain objects. A broken stair-case can be sent back to a time where it was no longer broken etc. Enemies can also be aged, slowing them, damaging them or in some cases outright killing them. This mechanic is cool, but I found it to be under-utilized in the game. Most of the time you'll simply be reparing a stair-case or similar thing, and then continuing on your way. While the combat implications are interesting, the resource cost of being able to age enemies way too high for me to justify using in most combat scenarios. In additon to the TMD's aging abilities, you get a half-life 2 style gravity gun, where you'll be able to pick up barrels and what not to throw at enemies, and finally you have the ability to create spheres where time is slowed down. It's a cool mechanic, that spices up the combat of the game. The weapons in the game are mostly your standard fair, you have your pistol, shotgun, automatic rifle etc. There's a few more interesting weapons, one weapon allows you to control the bullet midfliight, and another creates a ball that you can control directly, but these are mostly gimmicks that you won't use more than once or twice. After I got the Autocannon, I probably used that weapon 90% of the rest of the game. Enemy design is decent, with a fair amount of different ranged and melee attackers. There's a few boss fights, but they usually boil down to shoot the glowy spots on the enemy. There's an upgrade system for both your character and weapons, but these systems felt mostly inconsequential, outside of increasing my max hp. In the end, Singularity is a short (I clocked in at a bit less that 5 and a half hours), but solid FPS with some sorely underutilized mechanics that could of made the game amazing.Story wise, Singularity takes places in an alternate history world where the Soviet Union rises to power by utilizing an element known as E99. It is your job to to set the worlds time-line straight. The story utilizes standard time travel tropes decently enough, and the twist at the end is done well. The audiologs and flash-back scenes do a good job at creating an interesitng world. In the end, it's not the most orginial story, but it kept me interested and entertained until the end.Raven created a decent enough game, that's well worth buying at 5-10$. However in the end, Singularity is no Bioshock, and I would say it's not even as good as their earlier Wolfenstien title.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
Reviewing Singularity. A game about crazy Russian scientists.When I first started this game a while ago, I didn't really like it. Because of the slightly scary setting. But once you get used to the setting, it stays about the same and slowly decreases. But what is really interesting about this game is are the levels and the story. But the game also comes with a slight sense of humor. Sssia all the characters speak really broken English. Which made me giggle while playing through this mildly horroresque themed game.If you're a fan of the british TV series Doctor Who. You're really going to like this game. Because this game makes you travel in time. However linearly this game may be, you still can make one choice. But that doesn't really affect the games main story in any way. Though you cant really change the story, it's not really that bad. Because the story in itself is still really interesting. And makes you think how your actions could have led to this scenario.As an overall rating I whould rate this game 7/10 and whould definitly recommend it to a friend. Since this game plays like Call of Duty, but has a story like Half Life 2.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2011
												It was a good game but a kind of short game. It took me 7 hours to complete the single player. It was a great single  player game though. The graphics were great and gave the immersion affect. The sounds were eerie and kind of nerve racking at times. The story was easy to follow and fun to play through. The online portion of the game is dead. The special powers you get in game are fun to play around with and use to your advantage. You can kill the bad guys in unique and fun ways. The guns were very well done and there is gun were you control the bullet flight which makes for some good fire fights.The Russian language in the game was fun to read and understand what place was what in the buildings.There are 2 types of endings. The AI are standard but nothing really special, so you shouldn't need cheats to beat the game. The overall game was great but too short. When you pick this one up make sure its on sale. Its a great game and i recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
Solid 6/10I recommend this game when you can get it during Steam Sale. It is a short but lot of fun game and a very well made shooter.Nice gamemechanics and puzzles that are easy to solve but fun to experience.Environment, weapon and enemy designs are very well made and the setting of this game feels fitting and plausible.The weapon upgrade system is well made and rewards the player for spending time to search for upgrade points.The game is very short though and therefore not worth more than 10$ in my opinion. It does not really offer any replay value dispite having multiple endings and is absurdly easy even on the highest difficulty setting so it does not offer any kind of challenge.The story is a mess... it's all about time traveling, is filled with plot holes, does not make any sense and struggles with its own identity.See time travel stories are either:1, you create an alternate timeline because you are able to change the pastor2, there is no way to change the past because all the events have to happen in order to create the timeline you knowthis game wants to be both... for whatever reason.Some lore elements of the world you play in are actually very interesting and provide you with nice detail, but the core of it is confusing and without logic.If you can forgive this game for the strange time travel story and all the mistakes it contains you are left with a very well made but sadly way to easy shooter that is actually a lot of fun to play at least once.It should take you 3-5 hours for your first playthrough. (even on hard)

content:
Posted: July 25, 2011
												Singularity is Raven doing what Raven is known to do - delivering a solid first person shooter experience. Singularity takes elements of Bioshock [audio logs everywhere, similar-looking UI]; Timeshift [manipulate time]; Dead Space and Bioshock [machines everywhere to upgrade your equipment and skills]; and STALKER [takes place in Russia]; and Half-Life 2 [FPS games w/ puzzle sections]. Singularity is a game w/ lots of variety that often really hits or just misses its mark by a little bit. In the end, Raven delivers a solid experience that is worth your time - though, it just isn't anything special. Grade: C+.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 23
												Singularity is often overlooked because it didn't do so well when it was released back in 2010, which is a bit of a shame because this is a solid shooter with a pretty nice story, satisfying combat and a cool time shifting gameplay mechanic. It's also not hard to see that the game is heavily influenced by Half-Life 2.The graphics hold up well despite it's age and it runs smooth as butter without issues on modern systems like Windows 10. FOV is a bit of a problem though, being way too small, some people might experience motion sickness because of this. Luckily there are programs like Flawless Widescreen that will fix this easily without any tampering with the game files.The game is a little short though, it will take you about 7 to 8 hours to finish it and the ending is a bit lackluster. That said, this is Raven Software's last game before being swallowed up by Activision and being the developers of such classics as Hexen, Soldier of Fortune, the Star Wars Jedi Knight series and Wolfenstein, you know they can provide an action packed game and that's exactly what Singularity is, short but sweet, and well worth a purchase for any FPS fan.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16
												I first heard about this game roughly six years ago when I was first getting into FPS games. It was described to me as some sort of mashup of Half-Life and Metro. I looked up some videos and chalked it down as some generic activision broshooter.I was wrong.I don't really remember how this game ended up in my library. I think I'd last played it sometime in... 2013 or 2014? All I knew is I ended up liking it. I was scrolling through my library reorganizing all my games earlier today when I saw this game on the list and I thought to myself "somehow I don't remember anything about this game other than it being cool".I'm a couple hours into my second playthrough and yes, this game is as cool as I remember. I think if you want to more accurately describe it compared to other games, it's Half-Life meets Metro with a sprinkle of Bioshock and RE5/6. All in a good way. At it's core it's something of an action horror game. It's got a few jumpscares and the voice acting is hit and miss, but the level design, though linear, is well-paced and entertaining and the setpieces are beautiful. Just remember. Train boss. Remember. It's a good setpiece.Visually... It's a bit dated for a game released in 2010, considering it's an Xbox 360 port, but on a technical level, despite the lack of very advanced graphics settings, the game looks clean and crisp and it's not hard to look at. (I've picked a few screenshot-worthy scenes already.) Optimization is fine, can't say a lot on that front.All in all, I think this game has sooorta fallen out of the spotlight and just like me, I don't think a lot of people even remember it exists. Definitely a hidden gem at this point. Pick it up.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 5
												A really great, yet fantastic game. IF, yes IF it had used all its potential. Obviously the developers decided to neglect all the good ideas, but keep all the bad stuff. I'm somewhat in the middle of the game so far, but I'm already bored and I don't think I'll ever finish this one.Good things:- Time manipulation! Always has and always be a win!- The story, which also unfolds via notes and recordings you can find (and play / read) throughout the game.- The weapon lockers throughout the game, which lets you chose / change weapons. Awesome! Especially for a game which let's you keep only two weapons at a time.- A device which lets you degenerate / regenerate objects, slow down time, distort gravitation and other stuff. This is why I like videogames.And here are all the cliches that break the game for me:- I felt like I've always run out of ammo.- I dont' normally judge a game by it's graphics, but this game looks at least five years older than it actually is.- Protagonist can only sprint for about three meters, and even that feels super slow. Because we're playing as a elite soldier, and soldiers can't do more.- Strong, boss-like creatures only have one spot on the body where they are vulnerable. Because we all like bullet sponges!- I felt that it was depending on luck if you score a headshot or not. I have no problems in other games, but here it's like they're all sponges.- Escort mission! Yay. Can't make a game without it, right?- One of the absolutely best weapons I've ever seen in a game (which lets you guide bullets and has a massive impact on enemies) is only temporarely available. Because screw the player and the fun, right? We don't want him to have too much fun, now won't we? So better take this weapon away from him after using it.- "Defend the area / tower while some other dude tries to activate something and enemies spawn all over this effin place". Ah, an undying classic. A mediocre game is never complete without such a mission!- Forced stupid puzzles which are only good to prolong gameplay. I hated everyone of them.- The shotgun is extremely boring.- Bug-like enemies, which are fast, attack in hordes and are hard to hit. A, I love this one too, like every player does! Thanks for including this!It's really sad, because if they would have chosen to concentrate on the potential this game has, it had been a killer game.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												Singularity is one of those fun little gems that hides away in the corner of the steamstore which never really sees the light of day, when really it should have more recognition than its got. All i can say is thaqt this game is immencely enjoyable from start to finish; I it is one of the only game which has kept me entertained and intrigued throughout. Seriously there is rarely a dull moment in it, mainly I think because you're always slightly scared and creeped out by this mysterious island of Katorga-12 where it is set. Mind you this is no horror game, but it will give a nice dose scares throughout which will keep your toes most of the way through. Of course game can be frustrated sometimes when trying to work out puzzels, and a couple of enemy's may halt your progress for longer than is ideal, but still it rarely slows down with the action and intresting story.My recommendation is:If you want a game which tries something different, and gives a sort of breath of fresh air, pick it up when it's on sale, as £15 is a bit on the steep side. But is you want something fun to play, then just pick it up if you feel like it.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Finished the game in 11 hours, so it's not very long. Feels about as long as Bioshock 2. Although the game feels like a mix of BioShock, Metro, Prey,  It stands on its own very well. It features game play that slowly takes you through the start, explains the story and builds to full on combat,  The sound design is top notch and should be played with headphones to experience all it has to offer. Creepy atmosphere to start, detailed world, time travel, ever changing environments, action, suspense, puzzles, killing, weapon upgrades and mods, lots of hidden items to find, good story, great sound design, smooth controls. It's a game you enjoy taking your time to explore and play. Yes, it's linear game play, but the design makes you forget about it. There are extra rooms and areas to explore to find money, ammo, health packs etc. The only CONS I can think of 1. Too short Only about 12 hours2. No trading Cards3. No Mele combat abilities. 4. Few weaponsIt's a fun game and I enjoyed it so much I finished it in under 12 hours. Only a few gams have been able to suck me in to complete them and Singularity is one of them.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												"In Soviet Russia they had some really awful textures to look at back in 1955."I read quite a few user reviews before I bought this, like I always do. Some ppl call it hidden gem, masterpiece, etc. but to be honest it is somewhat average FPS with some interesting ideas here and there. I'm not someone who would care much about graphics but I think they were not considered very good even when this game came out, as I mentioned textures are pretty bad. The story, yes it has one, is vaguely interesting at least at first glance. But later on it slowly slips into swamp of time travelling bullcrap so I wouldn't say it's good. Maybe I'm just biased because I don't like time-travelling/alternate dimensions stuff. It actually features 3 different endings, none of them is particullary interesting and the one which could be considered a good ending doesn't make any sense due to involved paradoxes that are presented to you, Red Dwarf's ep. "Ouroboros" makes more sense and is more entertaining.Shooting itself is ok, nothing to write home about. Your arsenal consists of standart pistol, shotgun, assault rifle, sniper rifle, etc. There are few interesting pieces like rifle with homing bullets, which isn't standart arm since it is given to you only in certain parts of the game, or a grenade launcher with RC-like grenades (cool idea but sadly I didn't find it any good). You can also upgrade your weapons as long as you find weapon kits, but the impact of said upgrades is hardly noticeable, well you will obviously notice increased clip size but you don't really need increased dmg or reload speed. And I almost forgot that you can only carry 2 weapons at a time, personally I ended up using AR and minigun, this fact makes gimmicky weapons like that grenade launcher much less desireable.The game also has it's currency scattered throughout lvls, it's called E99 tech. It's spend on character upgrades, these are somewhat more impactful than weapon upgrades, or you can buy ammo with it but it's unlikely that you will ever find yourself low on ammo.What else? Oh right, Singularity's signature TMD. You can use it on enemies with various effects. It's used to solve ehm "puzzle" for the lack of better description and you can also use it to trivialize every enemy encounter once you aquire ability to make time-slowing bubble. This leads me to the fact that the game isn't difficult at all. Enemy soldiers have potatoe aim and you can easily avoid almost any attack from creatures. There is just one part which gave me a bit of trouble, it featured suicidal bugs.Overall it's slightly above average shooter, but only because few good ideas and the freighter level I really liked. It took me roughly 10 hour to beat on the highest difficulty.Buy it when it's on sale if you want to play FPS and can't think of any better than this one. Here's my reserved recommendation.
