content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												This game is amazing. You have a choice of using I think 9 or 10 different weapons ( a FRIKKIN MINIGUN IS ONE OF 'EM), good enemy variety, interesting story.They executed the concept of time manipulation so well that I never forgot about using those powers, and I never felt annoyed to have to use those powers. The Story is easy to get into, it's not vague or over the top.You might think it's attempting to be a horror game after the first 20 minutes of having played it, it's not. There are maybe 2 or 3 jumpscares in the entire game, just tiny instances that wouldn't really bother you.The level design is amazing, going back in time to the same place you're currently in, which was rusty and falling apart, then 50 years ago it's lookin' slick and futuristic, it's got a Wolfenstein: The New Order feel to it. The bosses are fantastic, they aren't hard to beat, they aren't pure BS in the sense that they attack for 2 minutes then have an open spot to shoot for 10 seconds. You're constantly fighting the bosses. You're constantly on edge.10/10. The price tag is a bit steep, but I'd recommend this any day. If it's ever on sale, you won't have to think twice about buying it (I hope).

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Wanna find out what happens when Half Life 2 meets Call of Duty? Raven Soft did.Pros - Legitimate Time Travel Plot- Secrets throughout the game- Dead Space style upgrade terminals for weapons and character- Optimized very well- Immersive- TMD is useful- Good characters that are for the most part fleshed out- Puzzle Gimmicks- Fun Boss fights- Multiple Endings- Time Stop/Slow-Mo GimmickCons - Generic Russian Enemies- Hardest Difficulties make the enemies feel like sponges- Felt very short- Press F and the puzzles are gone- Lack of control and ingame video optionsNot going to lie to you guys. This is a gem, a true gem. One of the best shooters from "Last Gen" and I am glad it was Raven Soft that  brought it to us, too bad the game is so short. The game itself revolves around the main character polluting the past and corrupting the future, obviously for spoiler reasons I won't say anymore about the story other than that. One of the biggest draws for me was the secrets. The secrets in this game feel very much like Bioshock. The customization reminds me so much of Dead Space, both of these, the secrets and customization, are NOT complaints. This game also has puzzles much like in Half Life 2 and the games special tool, the TMD (Time Manipulation Device) is used to solve many of them, this does lead into one of my biggest complaints about the game, when you press F the TMD displays foot prints on where to go next if you are lost, while nice, this ability has no drawbacks to prevent you from constantly using it, basically trivilizing one of the gimmicks this game has to offer just by pressing F. Pressing F also leads into my next point, control options and video options. This game has basically none of either, you can change a few basic controls but things like reloading are tied into the USE button as well, so things get very confusing, very quickly. Lastly, I would like to talk about general game design. In terms of actual character design and appearence everyone felt very generic, this is actually a bit ok though as the story itself is a big enough draw to keep you going, rather than the characters, who themselves have great personalities, just terrible designs. In terms of boss design, the few bosses this game has are ♥♥♥♥ing sweet, they all are very different and they are really fun, one of the ones in mid game felt very unique, I won't spoil it, but it involves a train. 10/10 - Despite the flaws, most specifically its length, the unique story, gameplay, and the time travel gimmicks help keep this game at the top of my list, I highly recommend this to lots of people, not very often a give a game a 10!

content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												Singularity is a great game, very under appreciated, it really deserves a sequel. It first comes out as a Bioshock rip off but I actually enjoyed a lot more than that game, it's a crazy mixture of that with Half-Life 2. And maybe inspired the end of Bioshock Infinite? This would not be the first time that a imitation inspire the original franchise.What it really needs improvement is the PC port of the game because this is obviously a direct X360 port, to confirm this  you just need to look at the low resolution of the textures outside of the main areas and, off course, the "Saving, do not turn off" warnings.The game don't have a lot of graphics options forcing you to go to REGEDIT to tweak the few extra options like Volumetric Light and Anisotropic filtering (Don't try to run it with the DX10 enable, the game don't support it , I don't even know why there is a option for that) and if you want anti-aliasing you need to force it in your graphics card options. And if the game suddenly don't want to start anymore just reinstall PhysX and will probably fix it.This needs a least a re-release with improved graphics, advanced options and with full steam integration.

content:
Posted: March 29
												This is the FPS you should be playing. It's fantastic. An FPS/RPG style hybrid where you find resources to upgrade your weapons and abilities. Abilities? Yes, you control TIME. Not just the cheesy slow bullets time either, but you can rapidly age doors to rust them off their hinges, reverse time to reconstruct a rotted bridge, etc. The center of the story is time manipulation, so you can kind of assume the story is all about time travel and the complexities of how that might work. The story isn't revolutionary, but it is well done. The shooting is fun and most of the combat feels very well balanced and executed. This is one of those hidden gems that simply did NOT get the attention it deserved.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												I just purchased this game for $7.49.  It was on sale for 75% off.  It's normally $29.99.  This is a great game, I remember playing it back when it was released.  This and Time Shift are 2 of my favorite games.  It's a pretty solid shooter with some fun elements to it.  The game runs great and looks great for pushing 6 years old.      At this point in time, I would NOT have purchased it if it weren't on sale, only because I've already played and beaten it before.  If I had never played it, I MIGHT consider paying the $30 price tag, but in my opinio that's just too high for a game this old.  It needs to drop considerably.  At least $20 or less... Maybe even down to $10.  I've seen amazing games only a few years old that are half the cost of this game.  Either way, this is a fun game to play, it's held up over time and runs great.  If you are interested in this game, buy it.  It's worth it.      From my understanding the multiplayer is kind of dead, can't really blame that on the devs.  They can offer the service but can't force people to play.  But don't let that stop you from playing a great game.I hope this review helped someone decide if they want to buy the game or not.  CK

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2011
												Looks good plays well and the control system is simple and easy to use its a fun ride and thats what it is a ride... The plot and story is great and is really fun to discover the various twists of what really happened although I cant go into to much detail without spoiling the story.The TMD device is fun and interesting but is really underused, there just isnt enough to do with it and the upgrade system although useful is not relevant enough that you can just bypass it totally.  Ammo is never an issue as there is just endless boxes and crates with ammo, similarly with med kids you will never run out they seem to be around every single corner and you can carry 5 with you (more with upgrades) so its really almost impossible to die or be stuck in a situation where you creep around with almost zero health praying for a med kid.Weapon loadout is varied although once you find your favorite weapon you will probably stick to it for most of the game.

Its like the newest Wolfenstein game with the excessive cliche German bad guys.Its got an interesting storyline, and its an atmospheric game.Next time its in a half-decent sale, its a must buy. Heck; its as essential a game to try as Half-Life 2 with the free HD update.Installed and ran first time.... Unlike Alien: Colonial Marines..... now that was a messed-up fergeaddabardit.Summary:`Singularity` reminds me of an adult Game version of what you find in Vietnamese War Museum pickle jars, due to Agent Orange.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												This is such a hugely underated game. It has taken a lot of elements from Half-Life 2, Dead Space, Resident Evil 4, and combined them really well into a game based on time travel and the Cold War.Complete with character and weapon upgrades, the ability to physically pick up and move items, the ability to age certain objects around you, and special abilities (such as instantly aging someone to death, or mutating a soldier into a disgusting creature, which will instantly attack other enemy soldiers).The engine is decent, it's clearly a console port, as the options are very limited, but it all looks fine and runs perfectly smoothly. The sound effects and music are great, and the weapons range from generic assault rifle and shotgun, to a sniper rifle that lets you move the bullet around in real time (like the Redeemer in Unreal Tournament). Which means you can snipe someone in the back of the head, despite being in front of them, and behind cover. It also features a grenade launch, which lets you manually control the grenade, almost like a remote control car (that blows up!).The plot is really impressive, with plenty of great time travel elements, horror, and decent characters.I really highly recommend getting this game. The only downside is that the game is very short (about 10 hours), so you may want to wait for it to go on sale. It does have a multi-player mode though, which may extend the lifespan.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2
												Singularity has some great thoughts to it but ultimately the circa-2007 graphics & lack of multiplayer kind of kill the fun for me. The graphics are reminicent of the classic FPS called Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory, which i've racked up several hundred hours on, but, Singularity is essentially Single-player only at this point in time (multiplayer is dead). Much like Quake4, the graphics are actually too chintzy to forgive & look past & the gameplay doesn't make up for it enough to be worthwhile to slog through. Doom3, even though it is of the same era, has an immediately engrossing 'scary horror thriller' type storyline going on that really takes you into the action. Doom4, of course, is a new classic, but that is unfair to mention since that game came out in 2016 so it has all the razzle-dazzle special effects that are possible in this day & age.The story is just too lacking in feminine influences to me.. are the guys homos or something? where are the broads... Anyways, what really put the nail in the coffin for this particular "scary FPS thriller" is the recent purchase of the remastered Metro 2033: Redux, which basically solved the things I thought were annoying about the first game of that series & it is a fun game again. In that game, there are both male and female characters who are active participants in the gameplay, & that makes it WAY more fun. No offense, but no chicks after a while just seems like a sausage-fest. just sayin'! The main protagonist is a guy & this isn't Tomb Raider or anything but it is a little more even-handed & there are couples flirting with each other & people trying to settle down & all that. Oh, and the storyline is excellent & you really get a feel for the events going on. It really takes you into what seems to be post-apocalyptic Russia of the year (you guessed it) 2033 in the future.Rating: 5/10 there are better sci-fi / scary FPS's out there to play instead. OK for it's time, but pretty bad graphically by modern FPS standards. Oh well. The Chipotle burrito & NOS soda I had with the game was good! That's gotta count for something. It was more fun to travel by ZX6r to the fast food restaurant & back to get some food while waiting for the game to load than the actual game.

content:
Posted: January 29
												There is a big design flaw right at the beginning. There's a point where if you don't grab the shotgun from the weapons locker, you'll empty all of your bullets in the next section. Then have no way to get more ammo or a different gun, and then for the section after that you have no bullets and no way to go back and get more. The only fix is to re-start the game from scratch if you don't make the right choice at that point. The design stinks, with bullet-sponge enemies and stingy ammunition drops. I've looked around on-line, and this is apparently a known problem. I don't see why this is so highly reviewed. Perhaps I did not get far enough into it to get to the good stuff, but this flaw so early in the game totally turned me off. I probably won't re-start and have to go through all of that again.

You can also use it on enemies by making them older which is just a "Press button and they die instantly" button. Not that it's even needed since the game is VERY easy. the only good thing about this game is the graphics, which look really good, especially for 2010. Thanks to the good graphics the atmosphere is good too, but that's where the quality stuff ends.Overall the game is generic, boring, and to top it all off the PC port is abysmal.1/5 (Hey, atleast it's not a 0/5) :P

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Singularity is ambitious. Singularity wants to play all sides of the field. Singularity wants to create an engaging and comprehensive FPS experience. Unfortunately for Singularity, it seems far too hollow to be great.This game isn't just a FPS. It is THE FPS. It is quintessential in all ways. Everything that embodies modern first person gaming is here and accounted for. The only notable exceptions are  chest high walls and turret sections. If you've played half life, or call of duty, then you've seen all this game has to offer. Nothing at all will surprise you here. You're better off looking elsewhere if you want an interesting first person shooter.Everything is just so standard. Singularity doesn't take any risks with the formula we're all familiar with. In fact, it seems proud of its influences. The protagonist is silent but gifted soldier who must save the world from countless monsters, the big bad guy, and droves of opposing soldiers. But wait, this protagonist has the power of a magic doohickey that can grab objects and alter the environment to solve basic puzzles. And also there's a scientist, and a secondary female character that shows up sometimes.Nothing is interesting about this game. It seems unable to make up its mind. Its hard to give complements after braving the constant, and I mean CONSTANT audio logs & mundane written notes lying around, the enemies that repeat the same two battlecries, a myriad of jumpscares; (or what I only could assume were supposed to be jumpscares,) a handful of unique enemy types, and a story that left me confused and annoyed. The game tired, I guess. But how many times can I see ghostly scenes of generic russian man #34 screaming, running away from something, or dying randomly before I just get bored and play something more effective at horror and a first person shooter experience. By the end of the game, I just wanted it to end. Not only did I stop paying attention to the plot, I had taken to throwing myself head first into enemies, which was just about the most significant source of fun this game has to offer. There are many better first person shooters to play.

												I played the game for about 3 hours so far and from what i can tell i cannot recommend the game based on what i have seen, only time it is recommendable is when its on severe discount.  First of all the hit detection is off, I blast enemies with weapons and unless im either using a sniper only time that i actual kill normally is in CQ.  The russion version magnum cant shoot crap outside of 5 to 6 meters otherwise I just make my target dance around but thats it, wasted two clips on a single russion soldier with no armor and all that happen was he flinched a few times and went right back so shooting me after i pumped clip after clip into him.  Story is interesting but still am working my way through it.  The time effect ability with objects is pretty cool, especially when it has you take a destroyed box and move it, regen it to make a portable staircase, then destroy it again and plop it under a half closed door and regen it again to make an entrance is pretty good.  Visuals are obviously dated, its a 6 year old game so that makes sense but it does its job well.  The game does the background introduction very bioshocky which is a nice touch but feels copied.  Random tape recorders and projection screens literally are pulled straight from Bioshock as if they blatantly stole their ideas!  Haven't fully completed the game but if the game is on sale for less than 10 dollars its a worth purchase if interested but dont buy it for any more than that!

number of helpful: 10 of 30 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												I'm into this game for about 4 hours now and I can clearly paint a picture of what I am dealing with here, and it is not pleasant. I will categorize my praise and critisism as far as possible - hopefully without losing focus.Game menue - Skip if not interested. But it gives you an initial idea of how lazy this port was.a) GraphicsIn the graphics menue you will be surprised to find only a choice of resolutions which will all leave your view narrow. With no option to manipulate FOV, since it is not for you to change, this sensation intensifies and gives even me headaches. And I honestly never had problems with FOV before this game - never felt I needed a slider. Additionally, you are able to change minor settings (depth of field, bloo, "high quality decals" - I'll get into this later) which are merely cosmetic but the developers do not seem to trust you with relevant stuff like AA or filtering. You can change your Vsync option, though.b) AudioYou will be faced by two possibilities: change your SFX and music volume. That's it. No way turning on subtitles, no choice of sound quality whatsoever. This is just poor!c) ControlsWhile you are able to change certain buttons, you will find yourself in the situation, that *reload* and *use* are assigned to one and the same button. No way of changing that. I am asking: Why? We own keyboards with more buttons than only 12. Laziness strikes again! There also seems to be a rudimental port option featuring aim assist. Other than that, there is no way to lie down or to check a box if you want to be in ironsights permanently or while clicking the RMB.Game worldFirst of all, I have to mention the horrible texture work all over the game,  especially when you're in the year 2010 and see abandoned structures . This and the fact that some textures are not in place at all makes me furious about the obviously lazy devs. I would, without joking, compare those textures to Half Life 1, which came out in 1998! Remember, that Singularity came out a few months after Metro 2033 in 2010. Neither from an atmospheric nor a graphical aspect I can't understand people who compare those games. They have nothing in common. In fact, it is an insult for the devs of A4 Games. I mean, Singularity has its atmospheric peaks here and there ( e.g. research labs, bug's layer ) but they are immediately destroyed by following "level design choices". I am talking about absent dynamic lights or objects (not even a flashlight,  which every modern soldier should have ), washed-out sky textures, which look frozen and unreal and cheap weather effects (e.g. rain). It's the same with the leveldesign. It is okay for the most part, nothing extraordinary. But there are so many moments where you will encounter unfinished structures and missing details (e.g. cut-off cables stop mid air and aren't modelled correctly). Unfortunately, there is some kind of physics engine, which is presented rarely. But when you encounter it, boxes will be flying around if you touch them or objects will get stuck and so on. It is super frustrating and happens at random! Other objects, like curbs, debris, bunsen burner nets, door handles, etc block you constantly. Mid-fight this is deadly and overall it is very disturbing to just get stuck in the middle of a room. You will get stuck randomly 1/3 rooms on average. This brings me to the games linearity (LOTS of poorly scripted events though), which does not have to be a bad thing. But this games crams it so far down your throat, that you just want to spit out. Invisible walls every other step, you aren't allowed to jump simple obstacles (like railings), there is no back tracking (doors magically close, invisible walls appear, etc) and there is massive hand holding, when following a fellow NPC. Just terrible and annoying. Unexcusable. On the other hand, you might be allowed to wander off the trail for a few paces: Take a corridor with several doors and one additional opens up for you to have ammo, health or E99 (coming to that later). So, searching in a very limited fashion is rewarded and present. Fighting/Guns/EnemiesThe game is a FPS in a classic fashion which has a focus on arcade gameplay (lots of medipacks, ammunition, buffs, guns, loads of enemies) that reminded me of Serious Sam and Wolfenstein at moments (just the arcade aspect!). If this was executed well, I would not have a problem with that. But the main thing that is terrible, is the KI. Enemies move as slow as if they were in slow motion, they run into walls for seconds and can see you through same. Why  soldiers from 1955 have the same guns as soldiers from 2010  will stay a mystery to me. Many enemies ( mutants and monsters ) are literally bullet sponges, including bosses - this is just something you should avoid, except for boss fights. They spice up the gameplay! At least there is variation in enemy design (at least optically), but fighting feels dull. You can wait in any corner you like for enemies to approach and pick them off one by one (dying animations do not vary a lot with most enemies) without being in real danger. It only gets dangerous when you need to heal, because you will slow down even more (yes, sprinting feels like you are dragging your boots through mud) and only heal 33% of your helath with a forevertaking animation, often leading to death by default. Besides standard guns (shotgun, pistol, assault rifle, etc), there are specials. One of which is the time traveling glove (see below) nourished with  newly discovered  atoms (called E99), which also serve as a means of payment for upgrades. Yes, you actually can upgrade yourself (health boost, accuracy, etc - also from blueprints you find) and your guns, which is an admirable system, although it has been in games (Dead Space) before. But a nice feature nonetheless. Unfortunately, weapon sounds and animations are not at the technical level of 2010 when the game came out and sound/look just awful (again: HL1 like). Story - pretty much a spoiler! The idea of time travelling has been done, of course, but I don't think, there was ever an approach comparable to this game. It is a great idea with nice implementations like portals (rip in the space-time continuum) and even little puzzles. Not like in Portal or Talos Principle of course, but I wished for something more like Half Life 2, since your time traveling glove can lift objects, drain enemies lifes, push them away, etc. Speaking of the "push effect" (basically an EMP) I need to say that it feels just so weak. Humans are pulverised into pieces which is surprising and satisfying, but mutants and monsters are merely pushed away a few meters. This is disappointing to say the least. The story in its entirety feels urged and flimsy. The voice acting does its part, because the actors often exeggarate and overemphasize their speaking parts. Stuff like letters, protocols, tape recorders or even movies try to keep the player interested but fail most of the time. The movies are the only thing interesting and even funny to an extent. Now the tough question after all that what feels like negative superiority. Would I recommend it? There is just so much clunky mechanics and minor mistakes combined with visible laziness that adds up to an infuriating melting pot of emotions. On the other hand, if you are only out for mindless and average designed FPS action, this might be something for you. As I expected more of this game, especially because of its praise in magazines and by other players, I can not recommend it. There is just too much missing, which I saw in games like Metro 2033, Half Life 2 or other story driven experiences with a character of linearity. I am not gonna put points on this game, because interest of players might differ too much.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												THE ONLINE IS DEADdo not get this game unless it is on salebut for all intents and purposes this is a rent-beat- return kinda game.I was taking my time triying to find hidden things and still beat the game within 6 hours. -Gameplay(7/10)Call of Duty with Time manipulation. controls are pretty smooth and simple. You can make a slowed time bubble shield, age SPECIFIC enemies and items, and get a force push ability that uses up a TMD meterYou get many passive perks (like holding breqath longer, more sprint, more health) and one avtive perk. for example: restore a little health/TMD every kill.The game is linear, only real choices are at the very end. There is a checkpoint right before the ending so you can see all three results.Dont get me wrong though, this game is really fun. Main flaw is needed more POWERS-Story (non specific spoilers) (4/10)(1st hour)There is an island with a special element that you go to investigate as a part of the US forces. once there you discover russia has time travel. you are flung back im time to a burning building and save ascientist. you return and find that that guy, Demichev, was SUPPOSED to die, and now he is the Russian Dictator trying to take over the rest of the world(bulk of game) You get this device called the TMD. it shifts time, but like the portal gun, only effects specific things in specific areas. You find two people aware of its exisence and help them through many linear levels gt to Demichevs base to stop him. (ending soft spoiler) kill demicev, kill scientist, kill both and become new ruler. No "Good guy ending"Lots of plot holes along the way there tho but it is rather hard to fill plot holes when you have time travelGraphics (7/10)Look nice and not demanding. Particle effects do their jobONLINE (0/10) There is no online because no one is still playingFinal Verdict (5/10)I use angry Joe's scale; 5 means that this game is average. but interesting to say the least

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												Singularity is probably a game you've played before with a different title. It kind of feels like a Metro/CoD mashup with too low a budget for any hope of living up to Metro's immersion or CoD's replayability. The combat is unrefined, NPCs are glitchy, weapons are unsatisfying, graphics are downright bad and moving your camera in a normal fashion expected of FPS gameplay might just give you a migraine. That last part could have just been me. I get what they were going for, but sadly this game is exactly what you'd expect based on the trailer and screenshots. If you're into playing an FPS a day, this one might be worth it, assuming it's cheap as heck. In general, though, SIngularity ain't worth your time. Oh, I almost forgot. At exactly 69 minutes into it I experienced a game breaking glitch that would have required me to restart the game since the "reload checkpoint" option didn't take me back far enough. I might have tried again but I decided 69 minutes fit well as Singularity's epitaph in my library.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												I waited a long time for this game to go on sale and I should have waited longer.  It wants to be Bioshock but fails on so many levels that I've just about given up on it.The story is decent and has some interesting concepts, but the mechanics are entirely inconsistent.  In the beginning you are given a knife, as you are given in all modern FPS's, but a few hours in the knife is removed and replaced with an Ironman style repulsor hand thing.  Sounds cool, right?  Not if the repulsor has a recharge delay and can only be used 3 times.  WIthin minutes of losing the knife I wanted it back.  Ammo is plentiful but there are no weapons to be had, so you spend hours collecting bullets for a rifle you had for about 20 minutes at the start and never get back.  I wanted to like this game.  It looks nice, it plays smoothly on my less-than-stellar machine, and it has a decent alternate history story like the recent Wolfenstein game.  But the lack of options when it comes to combat kills the momentum.  I can only shoot the same 4 guys in a corridor before I run out of the ammo I'm given before I quit.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												I think it stands as testament to how many years I've spent playing first person shooters that I can pick out all of Singularity's techniques that have been lifted from other games. Singularity's first person shooting mechanics are by and large influenced by Call of Duty with a hint of old-school flair. The time powers are largely bits of Bioshock dressed up with a time-travel vibe. System Shock 2 did its ghosts the same way Singularity does its ghosts. But the problem is with all these lock, stock, and barrel 'inspirations' is that the developers didn't bother to see what made them work, and so the game turns into a ♥♥♥♥ing mishmash of things that don't really work well together.There's all these cool weapons! But I ended up sticking with the assault rifle/shotgun duo because they are the most expedient at killing soldiers with guns/melee-focused brutes. There's an awful pistol, but I jumped away from that as soon as I got the assault rifle. There's a sniper rifle that acts like the one from Bulletstorm, but you can't store it in your weapon locker for some ludicrous ♥♥♥♥ing reason. There's a railgun with exploding rounds that's way less accurate than a standard railgun. There's a grenade launcher that you can secondary-fire to take manual control of the grenade, but Jesus Christ, I didn't spend all this time in Quake bouncing grenades off of walls and into ugly faces to be nannied by my own gun! These are all weapons with solutions in search of problems that never really materialize.While this game tries to innovate, it drops the ball in areas where it really shouldn't have. The game is adept at giving you a bunch of help messages and then being completely useless at pointing out exactly where you have to go! Audio logs are 'revolutionized', in that you have to wait in front of an audio log in order to hear it all, which breaks the flow of the game quite a lot. For a game focused around fast-paced running and gunning, it sure has a lot of ♥♥♥♥ing long-winded memos strewn around the place! And they're all information-and-flavor-light variants on "Something weird happened, technobabble technobabble technobabble, ow a mutant ate my arm, humans are the real monsters", etc., etc. The game sure has problems telling its own story, burdening down the player with a half-hour's worth of boring, poorly paced and told exposition before the player finally gets to shoot something. But since nobody pays attention to the story, let's focus on the real problem: The difficulty curve. Bioshock, the game that Singularity is drawing little hearts around in its notebook at school, has a proper difficulty curve and it requires you to stay competitive by ingesting plasmids and upgrading them. And by doing that, you slowly become one of the lunatics of the underwater insane asylum. Singularity, on the other hand, has a flat difficulty curve and its upgrades are just token bonuses. You are still the same old American Kick♥♥♥♥♥SuperCool Super Marine that's getting all the MLG 360 NOSCOPE HEADSHOTS, but you can choose to shave a fraction of a tenth off of your reload time on your shotgun. But if you don't choose to, no biggie! Just plug away! No stakes to raise, you're doing good! Everything is fine, just plug away until your shift's over!Singularity is a competent game, but it tries to be other games without understanding how those games became their own thing, and then subsequently fails to become its own thing. It's yet another plodding, mediocre mess from the fine folks at Raven Software.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												This is a linear  fps game with a  Soviet setting, an easy to understand plot, and very standard mesh of  gameplays of the era it was made. There is light rpg character building elements.The "novelty" is there are a lot of "puzzle" sections with solutions which require you use your abilities to progress to the next checkpoint. Generally there is only one way to solve these sections.Most of the "choices" this game offers are not needed. Most sections of the game already have a prescribed way in which they are best solved. So making one of your guns slightly better, or giving yourself more health can only really give you the illusion of choice. I don't reccomend this game because other than it's setting, it doesn't offer anything superior over Half-Life 2. A game which also  uses the same physics engine to manipulate objects in the world to solve puzzles.    You can use your "magic" abilities to fight the enemies as well. Though this is rarely needed unless it's the "point" of the particular puzzle section you are in. Overall this game got the reception it deserved for having such low expectations of itself.

												My major dislike about Singularity was the sudden spikes in the difficulty curve.   In a couple of the set pieces the difficulty spiked to being rage-quit-inducingly hard.Second to that the charecter voice acting was really, really quiet, making it almost impossible to follow the exposition being delivered by the game charecters (this is particularly bad for a time travel based game like Singularity).It felt like the time-travel/time manipulation mechanic was under-used and could have benefited from a more complete Portal-like exploration of the mechanics available to the player.The art and weapons are on par for an Unreal engine 3 game and solidly implemented.The plot felt weak and the finale nonsensical and un-satisfying. content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												I honestly do not understand what everyone finds so endearing about this game that I've read from the other reviews.  This is a horror game that mostly only uses jump scares, gross (but generic) monsters and eerie music.  This game has obviously aged and not particularly well which is a little sad for something only from 2010.The shooter mechanics are boring and unoriginal the guns aren't balanced even slightly.  The gunplay itself feels so unsatisfying as you will constantly wonder if you're making contact with the enemy as the usually never react to shots until they're dead or almost dead occasionally.  The secondary mechanics become repetitive very quickly and the age of the game really shows here because you will constantly see things you should be able to use with these mechanics but won't be able to so you can go through the exact script that the director had in mind.  The game is at least a little buggy I had it freeze on me just by reading a note.  It was at that point I just could barely take it anymore, but I kept going on for a little bit.The last straw for me was the suiciding insect enemies that come in waves and are more annoying than zoobats, you will get hit, you will die because you will have no idea where they're coming from until after 5 of them are hitting you from that direction at the same time.  Which is a hilarious contrast to the Russian soldiers you will fight which shout out where they're coming from and who go down quicker than star trek red shirts.  Maybe this one just wasn't for me, I don't know but I could find a lot of flaws here and the plot was intriguing it wasn't good enough to keep me interested past its flaws.

number of helpful: 12 of 42 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												It's a decent game, but it has a lot of technical problems and is missing some key features. If you liked Half Life 2, Bioshock and Timeshift, but for some reason don't want to play them again, you could buy Singularity. I would say it's not a good game, but a fun game. 4/10.Let's start with the bad. There are no subtitles. Just none, at all. Considering there are usually a lot of sounds and music in the background, and all characters speak with a Russian accent, this is a gigantic problem. Also, it's just rediculous for a game from 2010 to not have subtitles. The second problem are the options. There barely are any graphical options, and even less for audio options. The lack of the latter makes the subtitle problem even worse; you can't just lower the SFX or Music so you would hear the voices better. The graphical options might be a result from a (bad) port. Another minor result of this might be a problem with the controls. In the beginning of the game, you can use a melee attack. However, at some point you get a new power, which is binded to the melee key, and from this moment you can no longer use your melee attack. My guess would be that it's because it was the same button on console, they made it the same button on PC as well. This sucks, since the new power you get on that button is vastly inferior to your regular melee attack.Another control-related problem is the Use/Reload key. For some reason, they put both on the same key, and you can't change that. That means that you either don't have E as Use key, or the R as Reload. You get used to this quickly, but there is still no reason for this to be inconvienent.  The graphical options are bad, and possibly as a result, so are the actual graphics. The style is OK, but the texture quality is decent for the best objects, and it's terrible for some. There are some other problems that bothered me in the beginning, but I got used to fairly quick One of them was animations that would get interrupted by other animations, making it look rediculous. For instance, the recoil animation on your pistol is actually longer than the minimum time between shots, resulting the in recoiling animation ending halfway to display the shooting animation. They either should have made the animations as long as the action that they belong to, or they should have made them go over in eachother better.Another graphical problem is a minor problem with a specific weapon: You are sort of invisible. There is a special weapon that lets you guide a bullet, and it uses a bulled-mounted camera to do so. If you turn the bullet 180 degrees, and look at the position that your character is standing, there is nothing there. Nothing at all. In the meantime, your enemies do see you and keep firing at you. This looks rather rediculous; the enemies fire at thin air...That were most of the big complaints. It's quite a list, and it's the reason I would never call this a good game. I did however finish the game, and most of the time spent I enjoyed myself. That means there must some redeeming qualies.Actually, there is one. The gunplay. It's a shooter, and in the end the most important part is the combat. Which is very enjoyable. There are quite some weapons and they vary greatly. That is, however the only good part, and it's still not perfect. There are many weapons, but I used most of them only for a little while, before realizing it's vastly inferior to my main weapon: the Shotgun. It's so strong that it kills almost all enemies in one shot. With your sprint you are fast enough to avoid most damage, get up close, and one-hit them. This is fun, but it also means that it's not possible without thinking "This is so much weaker than the Shotgun" on most other weapons. The only other 2 weapons that I used sometimes were the Sniper and the Minigun, both to deal with enemies from afar. Apart from the gunplay, there's not much to the gameplay. You can use Time-powers in combat, but it's pointless. Depending on the enemy, it's either a useless slow, or an instant kill, and even if it's an instant kill it costs a ton of energy (you can only do this twice in a row, three with upgrades I guess), while you could also just use your shotgun for the same effect. I never had any ammo problems while I did have energy problems, and this is while I always used guns and very rarely the energy powers. The story is enjoyable, but predictable and full of plotholes and half-explained events. For instance, there are some occasions that you change things in the past that change the future (in big and small ways). The problem is that all characters seem to know this while there is no way they could know. The explanation they give has to do with leaving notes, but it makes no sense, and it would imply that everyone believes something because it's written on a wall somewhere. Another big problem with the story is a spoiler for the ending, so skip it if you want to.  In the end the big reveal is that you are the one who changed the past and messed up the world. You saved some scientist from a burning building, and the scientist became a Russian dictator controlling the world. They act like it's a big reveal, but it's glaringly obvious and if you payed any attention to the game you would have know it an hour in. That's not the only problem: the 'solution' they give for this problem is that you go back in time to when you save this scientist, and kill YOURSELF. So you can't just kill the scientist (for no reason whatsoever) and have to kill yourself from the past, creating a time paradox (aka plothole).  That were just some examples of mistakes in the story, and overall I would say this makes the story very forgettable.There are some more problems related to both story and gameplay. The first is the Time-Slow thing you can do while zoomed in with the Sniper. It's quite fun, but for some reason you can use this before you character ever comes in contact with Time-altering powers. It is a real Time power, and not just holding your breath or something, since it's called something like Time Dialation. There is no explanation given for this, whatsoever.The last thing I want to point out is the pointless use of the time altering power on objects. You can make objects yourger and older, which is used for puzzles and hidden areas. It's quite fun, but you can also use it on ammo chests, audio logs and stairs, in which case it's often just pointless waiting. If you find an audio log, instead of just listening to it, you have to repair it by making it new again (i.e. press the Q button) and wait for the animation. The same with ammo chests, and stairs; you just have to wait a second before you can use the object. The idea is fun, but if you have to wait a second before using any object it's just tedious and annoying. So overall, there's not much to this game. Nothing is exceptional, and the fun part (the shooting) get's harder to enjoy because of missing features and technical problems. In general, I think a 2010 game by Raven, published by Activision should have been much better, and it's just unacceptable to not have subtitles in this day and age. The concept was OK, and if they put a bit more time and effort in, I think it could be a very good shooter. Alas, now it's just a below-mediocore shooter. The only reason to buy this would be if all the things below are true:1. It's on sale for $5 or less. 2. You really liked Half Life 2, but have no desire to play it again.3. You really liked Bioshock, but have no desire to play it again.4. You really liked Timeshift, but have no desire to play it again.5. You don't like to listen to music while playing games (since if you do you won't hear a word from the story)6. You know you can get over major and minor problems in graphics, contols, and desing for the sake of enjoyable shooting.

number of helpful: 8 of 33 people (24%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												I didn't expect much, but I was surprised to find a ton of cool game mechanics. The ability to selective age objects, create time warp felds, slow down time when scoping, and use telekinesis opened up a lot of cool gameplay doors. These aren't, perhaps, new features - other games have tried it out before. But this game makes an effort to let you interact with tons of environmental objects, which is nice - it turned an otherwise standard shooter experience into something that felt pretty interactive.But the game's flaws outrank the fun. In order to get the sound to work, you need to disable any recording devices in Windows. The sensitivity bar won't allow you to go lower than a certain amount (which is still way too high), so instead of trying to find a config file, I just halved the DPI on my mouse. The FOV is artifically low (we're talking probably 65, here) so you get a claustrophobic sense of the world.I might have been able to forgive these shortcomings (and I did, for a few hours), but the real killer was the unbalanced gameplay. I handled giant mutants, blinking mutants, hordes of russians, and twisted undead with no problem. But at a specific point in the game, you're placed into the position of dealing with enemies who kill you in 2-3 shots, and which you're unable to really fight back against. The swarm of suicide bugs who, with three different hits, will kill you. The blade-armed assassin mutant who could take a literal dozen sniper shots to the head (!!) without being visibly damaged. These encounters took about half an hour to get past (a long time to spend in one encounter), with lots of frustration. And worst, they're surrounded by other no-problem encounters. I had thought to crank down the difficulty and cheese my way through these speedbumps, but you can't even do that.Add that to the game's general low-res appearance, uninteresting environments (someone said it was all brown - that's true), and unsatisfying sound; and the result was that I simply couldn't find a reason to continue playing.

number of helpful: 10 of 38 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Not really a bad game, it's just kind of an ugly, boring shooter that doesn't know what it wants to be. It starts out reminiscent of Bioshock, where you are in a facility where something has gone wrong and you only have notes and film projectors and such to seemingly place together the story. However, you then are introduced to the time travel mechanic and the game becomes a lot more plot heavy and "shootbang".  There's about a 2 hour interlude of sorts where everything slows down and there's a drastic darker tonal shift which makes the game resemble something more like Metro 2033. I suppose it's interesting to have a game that blends different styles together but instead of being its own thing, Singularity ends up just seeming rather incoherent. There's also plenty of sections where you are simply running down corridors and shooting up nameless goons, where it really doesn't resemble anything other than maybe Call of Duty, only without any real spectacle.The weapons are interesting, but I ended up using the assault rifle 90% of the time. Sure, I suppose you can say it's up to the play to spice up their loadout, but none of the enemies really suggested that anything else would have been a better option. The vigor/plasmid type powers are actually pretty cool and, unlike Bioshock Infinite, I found it pretty cool to not only rely on gunplay, but to also use the TMD abilities in the firefights as well. There's really only 2, maybe 2.5 "boss fights" in the game, which are interesting enough. The game doesn't look the greatest and there are a lot of bad bad textures.So if you've already played all of the Bioshock games and the Metro games and you want something vaguely similar and have a few days to spend on it, sure, grab this. Otherwise I can't really recommend it over any of those.

So Russia is involed.So, you're a black ops agent in an op in Russia and you decided to save a guy in the past. The butterfly effect therefore tells you to bend over and bow down to the soviet union as this new element, Adam- I mean, E99, has time manipulation abilities. You use your plasmids- I mean TMD, to freeze people and shoot them, age them, turn them into monsters, or teleketically grab objects to improve your abilities. You find shiney metal "Power to the People"- I mean, weapon boxes, to upgrade your weapon that absolutely no one has heard of, but are remarkable similar to the AK-47, a shotgun, a rail gun, a sniper, and other guns.The game is very liniar and eventually leads to a paradox that is just absolutely looked over. Then you disappear and become president of the US with the hand of God. cuz FUGGIN 'MERICA!!!"Is it worth $29.99 after 4 years of it's release? ♥♥♥♥ no. content:
Posted: July 18, 2012
												A generic Sci-Fi FPS that distinguishes itself by having a Time Reversal gameplay mechanic. Basically at a certain point in the game, you will get an equipment that lets you reverse or forward the effects of time on objects and enemies.Its an interesting concept that works well in some of the puzzles it presents, and the various interesting ways of dispatching your enemies. The basic FPS element in this game is however nothing special, and is as generic as the next FPS on the market.Sound is acceptable, with the usual standard clunks and effects one would expect. Music while good, is not particularly memorable and you will not be talking about it anytime soon after finishing the game.The story is interesting, if abit cliche. Its pretty short however, at only about 8 hours. While its a competent game in itself, it brings nothing special or revolutionary to the FPS genre.Overall Rating: 6.5 / 10An average run of the mill FPS with a few tricks. Give it a try if its on sale.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Being a fan of pretty much anything cold war, I'm probably not the best to write an impartial review on much based on it. However, I can't reccomend this game to anyone else.While the graphics are definately impressive, that's pretty much where the goodness stops. Gameplay is hideously repetitive, with the same old enemies in the same old waves. The story is hilariously bad, full of holes and poor twists and things that are brought up only to be immediately dropped ten minutes later, if the plot remembers it exists at all. The voice acting is laden with fake Russian accents, blown completely over the top. The fake RPG elements are pretty much pointless, with the upgrades doing little to affect much of everything.But the ability to shift stuff through time is pretty cool, but it also doesn't make up for the gaping holes in the rest of the game.

number of helpful: 5 of 27 people (19%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												A Mix bag of: Bioshock meeting Crysis, who both makeout with Dead Space, who's, in turn, seeing secretly Half-life! This epic romance made this child called Singularity! This game is strange in the sense that you'll feel that you've played it before ( if you played the other games then you did!!). The setting stage for this entertainment piece of software, its  a kind of "Cold War" roller coaster were you are a hero strangled  between past and future, and in the present(s) of both past and future. You will have to find a way to correct the past (Cold War), so that your future (Post Apocaliptic Cold War) will turn out great and then your present (Today i hope) will be fine! which makes this plot kind of messy!The Soviets antagonists are the  "Rambo III movie" type: super heavy accent, shoot to miss first, and ask no questions later, well... 'cause they haven't got any! The game is linear , but the annoying kind of linear, like you can't jump over a rock with the height of your knees, invisible barriers and debris who push you away from interesting sets. Mid game allies also are the only ones who can open certain doors. The soldier enemies have a set clock agenda to when to strike, some rush and then stay... and stay, until they are gun down!The female ally is a rip-off of Alyx from Half-Life 2, only eastern european, the doctor is the typical unconscious scientist (seen many times in James Bond Movies and Mission Impossible 2) who never thought the thing he created could possibly mess the world more than the Cold War itself! He gives a task and there you go, all the time, all the game.Were this game excels:The TMD - AKA "the mechanical plasmid"- that lets you control time, degrades boxes, electrical boxes and turn humans into monsters later on. Visually and graphic wise its very impressive when you turn a oxidated torn apart train to its ancient glory.The Monsters - AKA "the soviet splicers/necromorphs" - hyper deformed former soldiers and habitants of the isle, who are agressive and fight in packs (sometimes), some have nice "powers". The mini bosses are tough and challenging. The Seeker Rifle - AKA " Curved bullet Wanted movie ability in a stick" - the description speaks for it self, slow pace bullet in slow time. The Ending- 3 possible endings! Were is not very good:The setting - Cold War? Seriously!?  The sounds - Soldiers have only 3 phrases, they speak 2 and repeat the last one until their deaths or yours, and in every room there is a sound for every a balcony bell, for dead phones and typewriters, wich make no difference in the game or plot wise Visually - The graphics, seem rushed and random there are glitches, the hero has a tendency to get stuck.The upgrade TMD\Hero\Weapons system - only 10 - 30 % of upgrades  are actually usefull, the others are thrown just to keep you occupied.The Endings - the endings could be something epic, but its disappointing, because in the 3 possible ending its focus in the same mistake, when the solution which is quite obvious its ignored... some say its on purpose because a sequel was in the works for this game... still very bad choice!Not worth to buy, but reasonable to play, if only to use the TMD

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												You know those games that create a unique, compelling, immersive world?  This is not one of those games.This game reminded me strongly of the Russian-created game, "You Are Empty," which also sends you through a destroyed world created by Soviet super-science gone horribly awry - AND involves time travel.  One detail - "You Are Empty" came out in 2007.  Hmm.  Funny, that.Anyway, though "You are Empty" feels like a game created by a small indie studio, the super-Soviet world they created felt more authentic than the one in Singularity, created by big studio Raven Software.I am still playing it, but my biggest pet peeve so far is when they have English text with silly things like backwards 'R's, I suppose to make it seem Russian.Anyway, the gameplay is reasonable, though not particularly inspired, so if you get it cheap enough, and you aren't expecting much, you should have some fun. My "thumbs down" is based on the current price of $29.99.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												Couldn't get into it. Singularity has a lot of interesting ideas, but takes advantage of none of them. The game's big gimmick, the TMD, is nothing more than a contextual extra "use" key. While it has other abilities to use against enemies, none of them I encountered were entirely necessary to use. This is mostly because the game's assault rifle is the greatest weapon ever created in the history gaming. With plentiful ammo, high accuracy, low recoil, and able to take out most common enemies with one headshot, there is no real reason to use any other weapon. It's effectiveness causes the novelty of the games "unique" weapons to wear off very fast. Sure, you can use the gun that allows you to guide bullets into enemies around cover, or slightly out of your line of sight. But in the time it takes for you to guide that bullet into a single enemy, you can kill that same enemy and his 5 comrades, and the rest of his reinforcements in the same amount of time with that godlike assault rifle. There is nothing else to the gunplay, just shoot them in the face with the AR and gg. You can't even throw grenades. You'll find more depth in a CoD game, which is an impressive feat I must admit.Beyond the boring gunplay there is not much else of merit. The story suffers the same logical inconsistencies of any story involving time travel. My favorite part was going back in time to stop the evil Russian general from killing the good scientist, and after bursting into the room, unloading 10+ bullets into his face and blasting him through the window several stories above the ground, he ends up surviving and going on to rule the world. ♥♥♥♥in Russians man. The characters are dull cliches ripped off from other, better games. The evil general, the good scientist, and the random woman helping you are basically the Russian copies of Dr. Breen, Dr. Kleiner, and Alyx from HL2. There's also the incredibly generic soldier buddy that you'll find by the dozens in any CoD game. You spend about the first 30 minutes of the game with him until he gets shot in the face by the general because he's a stupid ♥♥♥♥ing moron. This of course is after you get randomly sent back in time and accidentally save the general because you're a stupid ♥♥♥♥ing moron as well. The only interesting attribute of any of them was the well modelled♥♥♥♥♥of the woman, but I digress...Overall, Singularity is an incredibly bland shooter with some well conceptualized yet poorly executed ideas. If you absolutely must try it however, or you think I'm full of♥♥♥♥♥♥ at the very least wait to buy it when it's on sale for $5 or less.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2011
												Corridor shooter with all the modern FPS garbage checkboxes marked off. 2 weapon limit, boring "realistic" weapon selection, virtually unlimited ammo and health kits, clausterphobicly linear, and enemies that range from boring to ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Tries to steal all the best elements from recent releases but ends up feeling more like someone tried to glue together a jigsaw puzzle instead of solving it. There are some beautiful sets with great texture work & models but the glaringly awful random bad textures cancel out most of them. Probably the most infuriating part is that even with multiple endings they are all BAD END. Multiplayer is consolified "Quick Match" matchmaking only with no lobby system or friends-only private games. There are upgrade systems for your weapons and character but if you are thorough (which it isn't hard to be in a corridor shooter) you will have everything maxed by the end of the game anyway.This game is the cancer killing the industry. Don't bother.

When I awoke several hours later, the two paramedics now standing over me, took very little pleasure in informing me, than due to almost unbelievable levels of intoxication, my liver was now damaged beyond all hope of repair. To summarise, if you played Bioshock and thought to yourself "This game is too good, I actually prefer my gaming experiences to be far more generic and around four-fifths ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ than this", then my friend, Singularity, is for you.

												When I first started playing this, I thought that it was an interesting concept for a game. However, the further I got, the less I liked it. The reason why I don't like it is because it tries to be several different games at once. To the best of my knowledge, it tries to be Half Life 2, Bioshock, Timeshift, and Modern Warfare at the same time. If implemented correctly, it could be an interesting game but it just doesn't work. In fact, I was so bored by the game that by the time I got to the end, I didn't even care what happened to any of the characters anymore. That's pretty much why I didn't like this game; it's because it's boring.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												Game has multiple plot holes which can easily be explained away by the fact that time travel in this game is dependent on the element E-99. If a subject (living or not) does not have any amount of E-99, then time changes upon said subject is nil.Now, depending on the amount of E-99 in a subject (we are talking particles here), then the more "powerful" the time changes is on the subject.That's a big premise to the game. You just can age or make new every and any thing in the game. Graphics are fine. Weapons are nice. You can upgrade your weapons, your time manipulation device, and Renko, which you play as.Story is...meh. Multiple endings. Missing one in my opinion.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2010
												I have been a long time fan of Raven Software ever since discovering Jedi Knight 2 when I was a wee 9th grader. Last year's Wolfenstein was a bit tedious after you got into the meat of the game, yet was still quite entertaining to me. Starting Singularity, I was immediately captivated and interested in where the story was heading, invoking a cheesy albeit charming science-fiction-B-movie feel. The pacing is great and the game mechanics heavily remind me of a hybrid of Half-Life 2 and Bioshock. I was honestly taken aback by how much I liked this game, though the $50 pricetag is steep for a June 2010 release (I bought it in October for the full $60!). I say it was still worth it though, they deserve my money, they did quite well!

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												I love time travel stories - and this delivers!*minor spoilers*Yes, it is very linear. Yes, the story is not *that* original. And yes, in normal difficulty the game throws medipacks and ammo at you continously so that you never need to worry. There are some easy-to-solve switch puzzles that make for rather quiet situations, followed by explosive killfests with mangled bodies flying around. The weapons are awesome, especially the "experimental" stuff like the steerable bullet that make your targets explode in a fountain of flesh and blood. Very satisfying :)Although the story isn't outstanding, it is brilliantly told! Scripted events, explosions, dialogues, story twists... the Half Life-Formula is working great. The level design is good enough to let you dive into the world - which is disturbed by invisible walls you often walk into. Overall I was entertained from start to end - and that is what I want when I play a science fiction FPS ;)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												Okay. I am going to start this out by saying something: THIS IS A HORROR GAME.I personally picked it up because I enjoy games with interesting twists, like using time in combat. Nowhere said that this game is scarey. It ♥♥♥♥ing is.That said, lets review:THE GOOD:Time and combat work very well together, you can (once you get the right upgrades) slow/nearly stop time, blast people's legs, arms and heads off, age/reduce in age objects, people, and mutants, as well as shoot them up with a big♥♥♥♥♥shotgun, or whatever else you fancy.If the game is meant to do horror, it does it well (for me), with various jumpscares that are very nicely implimented (ie. scare the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you since you don't expect them), and the atmosphere is one of uncomfortable ruins.The shooting works. You shoot people, if you shoot them enough, they die. The guns sound quite weak, which is normal for modern shooters, but people react to some extent when shot (especially with the shotgun)Basic upgrade system for guns, with some customisation for your time powers, and various perks you can get.New mechanics are added constantly through the game, so you never feel like your game is stagnating.Although the game is completely linear in its story until the end (2 endings and a 'hidden' ending), there are plenty of areas to explore that can add 1-3 hours onto the game (its about 6 hours if you just follow the footsteps)THE BADThe plot is a little hard to follow at times, and there are some questions at the end I just want answering, and don't seem to be answered. I won't leave them here as they WILL spoil the game for you.The AI is a little off. People with guns will generally either stay where they are (which is typically in the middle of a corridor with no cover) or just run to their set position and start firing. Mutants just run towards you on the shortest trajectory.Not many bosses as such, only a couple of points where you meet more powerful mutants that are annoying to kill. To make up for that, you have a couple of timed RUN AWAY sequences. Yay.One of the time powers is really annoying to set off, as it involves pressing the button for another power twice quickly, which rarely works. I guess this is probably a legacy from consoles, where you have about 8 buttons for everything.The description on the store page isn't quite telling the truth. You do no 'travel seamlessly between 1955 and 2010'. The game pretty much orders you into a rift so you can go back in time, do something to alter the future, then go back into the present to carry on as normal. You don't get the choice of when you want to go back, you just have to.The UglyThe graphics are quickly aging, and not terribly gracefully.Those mutants are not going to win any beauty contests any time soon.Overall score: 74/100. If you like horror FPS games, pick it up, if not, then its probably for the best to leave it. I got it on sale and it was well worth the cost, even if it did leave me with a couple of nights when I regretted playing it in the evening.

												I just beat this game (got it during a steam sale for $10) Well worth the purchase!I would say the graphics themselves are only about a 7.5... (but they used them well!)It was a very atmospheric game, (very immersive) It draws you in very easily. Story is good, and ending isn't all that typical... (music adds to it and is pretty good, nothing that noticably stands out on its own though)The performance of the game is pretty Stellar, I mean its smooth (Max @1080p, 8x AA, 16x AF, 4xSSAA transparent surfaces) kept a constant 60 fps (minus one or two areas, not noticable to 99% of gamers out there) The weapons (although the selection isnt massive, meaning there isnt a lot to choose from, but there is enough) They are unique, and the actual gunplay is fun, and the ways to kill using your special skills and technologies! It was a fantastic game and Highly recommend it to any of my friends who are fans of FPS. This is based solely off of the single player campaign!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												I love time travel stories - and this delivers!*minor spoilers*Yes, it is very linear. Yes, the story is not *that* original. And yes, in normal difficulty the game throws medipacks and ammo at you continously so that you never need to worry. There are some easy-to-solve switch puzzles that make for rather quiet situations, followed by explosive killfests with mangled bodies flying around. The weapons are awesome, especially the "experimental" stuff like the steerable bullet that make your targets explode in a fountain of flesh and blood. Very satisfying :)Although the story isn't outstanding, it is brilliantly told! Scripted events, explosions, dialogues, story twists... the Half Life-Formula is working great. The level design is good enough to let you dive into the world - which is disturbed by invisible walls you often walk into. Overall I was entertained from start to end - and that is what I want when I play a science fiction FPS ;)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												I'd say that Singularity is underrated considering I've not heard much about it; I decided to buy it during the summer sale.  It took me about 8 hours to complete and I enjoyed the gameplay. I was probably about two hours in before the game picked up so if you're feeling bored at first, don't be too discouraged to continue on. You're given the Time Distortion Device and are able to upgrade it throughout the game. The TMD lets you solve puzzles and perform combination attacks on enemies. The combat was fun and the boss fights were also fun; you're given at least a couple options for killing things so it is entertaining in that aspect. There are notes to read and audio logs to listen to throughout the game that will help fill in the story.I enjoyed the audio and the graphics were decent but consider that this game was made in 2010 so the visuals aren't just awesome. There is no anti-aliasing setting in the game's options but you can simply override that in the NVIDIA Control Panel and it should work. I likely won't replay the game since I read everything the first time through, but it was worth the sale price.

												Good graphics, very distinct almost alien landscapes at times.Good gameplay (although NPC AI is basic, the idea is generally to kill enemies asap not marvel at their cognative abilitys, am i right?)Decent story with multiple endings, several shocks to be had but more creepy than horror for the most part.The time control mechanic is well implimented and fun as is the game in general, as well as having several functions blatantly ripped from valves "gravity gun" mechanic.Play time clocks in at around 6 - 9 hours of solid gameplay, which is about average as far as FPS' go.no bugs to report on my playthrough, however i did at certain points get 10 second freezes (around 6 or so in complete play through) however that could be a problem on my end as easy as it was the games. A far better effort than generally to be had from russian developers and more polished to boot.... like metro 2033 but not pants

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
Short AnswerShould you buy it - $30 is a little bit much for a four year old game but it is a good game and if you really like FPS's, YesShould you buy it on sale - AbsolutelyLong AnswerSingularity is a standard FPS with just a little bit more that sets it above the norm.Visuals : The visuals in the game wont destroy your graphics card or anything but it does tax it a little bit. The scenery and set pieces look very nice, sometimes really pretty. There is no reuse of areas that I can tell ( aka same corridor syndrome ) and you will get a good feeling of progression ( you can visually see getting closer to your goal). The enemies look nice but dont change much in the looks area but at least you dont get the same guy but his time hes red! Overall - Good looking game that helps to visually immerse you into the world.Story and Setting : (Spoiler Free) The setting is an Island off the coast of Russia that has some dirty little secrets and as a US special forces soldier you have to infiltrate the island and find out what is going on. As a base story it is just like most of the other FPS games out there but Singularity adds a nice twist on the basic formula that makes it feel new and refreshing. Overall - The story wont break the bank on amazing plots but it will engage you very well and help to keep you playing to find out what happens next.Gameplay : This is were the game really sets itself above a normal FPS. It has a slight rpg feel with upgradeable weapons and skill selecting although neither is a game changer or breaker. It has good gun play and the powers that you use are fun and work well but what this game does really well is that it lets you play the way you want to. No, there is no stealth or anything like that, it is all action and if something is in your way it has to die but the game gives you incredible freedom on how it dies.   You can play and complete this entire game with nothing but guns or once you get your powers you can complete the entire game with those. It never limits you and it gives you plenty of ammo or easily throwable items no matter which way you want to play. Overall - The gameplay is great and gives you a great feel of freedom that never tells you how you should play it Replayability : While the story does give this game a little bit of replay ( you might want to play again just to see all the clues you didnt understand in the first playthrough ) and the gameplay lets you play it again in differnet ways, there is really no reason to play it more than a few times.Personal overall enjoyment - This game was a good change of pace to me for normal FPS's. I enjoyed playing the game and was glad of the purchase I made. I will probably play it again sometime down the line and have no problem recommending it as a good game.

												A very good game. A bit easy on "normal" but had some difficult parts even then.You are a member secret military strike force with a mission into the heart of Russia. content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												I really liked it. I am surprised it was published by Activision as all they really do now is COD. A much better shooter than COD has ever been and liekly ever will be. Shame we didn't get a sequel. I am not going to give it a score but I will give it pro's and cons.+Nice lighting effects and pretty descent graphics esspecially for it's time.+Nice fairly original story+Fairly interesting characters+Good monster and enemy design+Fairly interestign guns+Nice not in-your face progression+Good level design, also good puzzle design. Puzzles are nto stupid hard btu nto really easy either and there are not too many of them either.-Gun sounds need more work. Not very punchy sounding. The Magnum style gun in particular and the sniper rifle.-A bit short hwoever if you want a short game this is perfect. I completed it in 7 hours. I explored everywhere as well.-Gun's could have been a bit more interesting. Mabe a secondary ability on the autocannon would have been nice adn the shotgun.-Progression system and weapon upgrades are very boring. Would have liked to have seen some E-99 infused guns like the autocannon rounds fired E-99 shells, fires slower but packs a hell of a punch. That would have been cool.-No side quests.-Linear game but encourages exploration.-Difficulty is a strange one. I would have liked to have seen a setting between Medium and Hard. Hard is stupid difficult and Medium is just too easy.There arfe probably more pro's and con's but I cannot think of them all.I decided to give it a score in the end but at the end so you ahve to read it all......hahahah.I give it an above average of 6/10. In comaprison I would give BF4 a 5/10 so thats pretty good. Average is a 5 and this game is not average in anything. An overall great game if I am honest and is great value for only £2 soemthing.EditThe game is a great PC port. There are a descent amount of settings. Nice sound assets other then the guns. Frame rate is wanderful. FOV seems to be ok with this game in retrospect I play all my games at at least 95-100 if I can. This game is probably 80 around that but it feels very pleasant to play for me.
