number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												I awaited a bit long for a sale before buying this game; I must say that I shouldn't have awaited so long and just bought it at full price, because it worth it.Around the internet you'll see some people comparing Singularity to Half-Life 2 and Bioshock, so I'll compare too, but I'll show what points those games has in common with Singularity, so you can form your own opinion. Story You play as captain Nathaniel Renko, who comes to a misterious island called Katorga-12 after the military has received some signs of radiation while its radar was passing by the Eastern Russia; when you arrive at the island, it is a desolate place, abandoned long ago for unknown reasons, while some kind of military reasearch has gone completely wrong when the russians discovered a new element called E-99. Gameplay Some people say that this desolated island has some resemblance with Bioshock's rapture or even Half-Life 2's City 17, because of the abandoned post-apocalyptic feel it has; but Katorga-12 has its own charm, you can think it as a second Chernobyl (if you played the Stalker series you'll know what I'm talking about). People who used to live there abandoned their normal lives for good, leaving papers on the tables, schools are full of children drawnings and kitchens are still filled with canned food and pots. It's a wonderful game, full of places to explore and learn about what happened in the island, and Singularity really rewards exploration, so please, don't rush while playing this game, take your time because you'll be rewarded with secrets that only the devs at Raven could have done so well. Most of the plot is explained by notes you find scattered around the buildings and audio logs. Some are well hidden, requiring even a bit of thinking before you can reach them, which I myself think it's just awesome. This is a feature that you'll find in Bioshock, but in Singularity I find it particularly better, because the voice acting is just perfect (at the beggining of the game you'll hear some audio logs made by the children themselves, trust me, it'll give you some chills). There is a couple more features that will bring Bioshock to mind, for instance the way you collect items in the game: you must interact with them pressing a key, only ammo you can actually pick up running above them; the health system isn't regenerative as in most shooters, you must collect aid packs to use later pressing another key, as with Bioshock. Singularity has kind of the same pace as Bioshock, that is having you searching the place for clues, secrets and items, then entering in some fire-fights. During the action scenes you can use a very well selected variety of weapons, and it doesn't limit itself with the everyday shotgun and machine gun: you have weapons that let you literaly guide the bullet, and even a grenade launcher that let you "drive" the grenade around the environment; even the usual sniper rifle has a feature that let you slow down time to aim well at your targets. Unlike in Bioshock, in Singularity you really feel the 'oomph' of the weapons, they aren't just pea shooters and the enemies aren't bullet sponges who just loves to break your immersion. I wouldn't call Singularity a shooter, because it has more to offer; but when you have to shoot somebody, it does well, with solid shooter mechanics, reload animations and weapon upgrades.The main feature of the game is presented by the Time Manipulating Device, or TMD, which works as a glove that you wear in your left hand. With it, you can solve puzzles buy aging and renewing some objects, like crates, stairs and machinery. As you progress within that game, you can upgrade it with new powers, just like you do with the plasmids found in Bioshock, but as I said, Singularity has its own charm, it only takes inspiration in Bioshock, although sometimes I felt as it was the other way around, because everything Singularity does, it does better than Bioshock. These new powers let you launch pulse explosions, create bubbles that stops time within it, age enemies until they're just a pile of dust and manipulate objects just like the Gravity Gun (again, Half-Life 2).Singularity has a total of three endings that conclude the narrative in three awesome and distinct ways, that you would finish in something like 8 hours or so. Sounds Everything in this game sounds good: the voice acting, gun shots, explosions, the russian lines spoken by some enemies, the soundtrack that changes accordingly... It's everything well done. Technically I saw some people saying it runs badly, but it is one of those games that was completely polished and well optimized; I could reach 120fps (it doesn't have fps limit as most games out there), and my PC is kind of mid range: i5 2400 3.10GHz, 8GB ram, Windows 7 64bits and a GTX650 1GB.So, if you are the kind of gamer who likes plot oriented games, with a good shooting mechanics and full of out of the ordinary places to explore, just like Half-Life and Bioshock, you definitely should give SIngularity a go. But don't expect a rip off, because this game was well done, it has all of the Raven style that old gamers love and it's really one of its kind.

Posted: September 30, 2015
												Obviously has aspects from other games, most notably Bioshock, and doesn't look that great when compared to them. However, taken on its own it's a solid FPS with good controls, solid weapons and a decent enough storyline.Singularity isn't groundbreaking and now I've completed it I doubt I'll replay it any time soon. What it is is a fun FPS that is well worth playing through.Oddest thing for me is that many aspects of the game mirror Bioshock, which is a game I both love and loath. Singularity simply doesn't quite manage to pull off the atmosphere or the immersive world that Bioshock does, on the other hand I find the controls for Bioshock horribly clunky  while Singularity is beautifully smooth. In a year or so if I'm looking for an 'experience' I'll load up Bioshock... if I'm looking for a bit of FPS no-brain violence I may well choose Singularity.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 12, 2013
												Singularity is a fantastic singleplayer FPS. In the tradition of all the B-tier shooters in the 90's this game, like Bioshock, takes solid shooting mechanics, wraps in a unique gameplay twist and presents an interesting setting for the game to unfold.The setting is an abandoned Russian facility that did experiments on a mysterious substance that affects time. That's the gameplay hook, you explore by dilating time and the age of objects around you. You can make enemies decay right in front of you. It's a fun experience.Unfortunate for the developer Raven, Activision sent this solid gem to die at retail with no advertising support and so the game was religated to obscurity. I'm sure the multiplayer is dead at this point but the singleplayer alone is worth the price of admission.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												A fantastic shooter with great mechanics, story and satiesfying gunplay.In some way the story goes down the bioshock infite route, but is more interesting and you can have different endings as well. It is a much better shooter than Bioshock infinite though except the fact that the world of Bioshock is truly special. Singularity also goes down the horror and atmosphere route quite effectively.The graphics of this game on the other hand are really good despite its age, except that it can be a tad bit "brown" even though it suits the setting. It is a quality game with great detail and animation.The only big negative (which can be fixed quite easily) is that the FOV is truly awful and can't be changed in the game itself. I guess the game was developed with a consoles in mind. I would say it is actually unplayable unless you fix this. I installed "flawless windescreen", a free program who easily remedies the problem. There might be other ways as well. Really, don't play this game without the fix.A truly great game that for some reason seems to have gone a bit under the radar. One of the better shooters I have tried so far.Well reckommended.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												The story was interesting and unique, despite the characters who you never really feel any attachment to.  A variety of weapons was nice to see, but the weapons system could've been better handeled--specifically the upgrades.  Rather than having upgrades to counter the weaknesses that the weapons all had, each weapon unfortunately all had the same upgrades of Clip Capacity (hold more ammo overall), Reload Speed, and Damage.  The system could've easily taken into account the charge factor for the railgun and decreased the amount of time that it took to charge, for instance, or it could've given the grenade launcher a higher range--different upgrades depending on the weapon, to overcome the respective weapon's weaknesses.  It was also nice to see a variety of enemies.The overall singleplayer campaign is roughly 10 hours long, but it is an interesting game, and I certainly recommend it if you can overlook its flaws.  I'd give it an 8/10, only because of the seemingly lazy implementation of weapons upgrades (as opposed to character upgrades), and that they could've fleshed out the characters a bit more and made you actually feel some sort of sentiment or attachment to said characters.  Also, the suicide-bombing swarm bug enemies (I think they were called Phase Ticks).  Seriously, screw those guys.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2010
												I have been a long time fan of Raven Software ever since discovering Jedi Knight 2 when I was a wee 9th grader. Last year's Wolfenstein was a bit tedious after you got into the meat of the game, yet was still quite entertaining to me. Starting Singularity, I was immediately captivated and interested in where the story was heading, invoking a cheesy albeit charming science-fiction-B-movie feel. The pacing is great and the game mechanics heavily remind me of a hybrid of Half-Life 2 and Bioshock. I was honestly taken aback by how much I liked this game, though the $50 pricetag is steep for a June 2010 release (I bought it in October for the full $60!). I say it was still worth it though, they deserve my money, they did quite well!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												Okay. I am going to start this out by saying something: THIS IS A HORROR GAME.I personally picked it up because I enjoy games with interesting twists, like using time in combat. Nowhere said that this game is scarey. It ♥♥♥♥ing is.That said, lets review:THE GOOD:Time and combat work very well together, you can (once you get the right upgrades) slow/nearly stop time, blast people's legs, arms and heads off, age/reduce in age objects, people, and mutants, as well as shoot them up with a big♥♥♥♥♥shotgun, or whatever else you fancy.If the game is meant to do horror, it does it well (for me), with various jumpscares that are very nicely implimented (ie. scare the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you since you don't expect them), and the atmosphere is one of uncomfortable ruins.The shooting works. You shoot people, if you shoot them enough, they die. The guns sound quite weak, which is normal for modern shooters, but people react to some extent when shot (especially with the shotgun)Basic upgrade system for guns, with some customisation for your time powers, and various perks you can get.New mechanics are added constantly through the game, so you never feel like your game is stagnating.Although the game is completely linear in its story until the end (2 endings and a 'hidden' ending), there are plenty of areas to explore that can add 1-3 hours onto the game (its about 6 hours if you just follow the footsteps)THE BADThe plot is a little hard to follow at times, and there are some questions at the end I just want answering, and don't seem to be answered. I won't leave them here as they WILL spoil the game for you.The AI is a little off. People with guns will generally either stay where they are (which is typically in the middle of a corridor with no cover) or just run to their set position and start firing. Mutants just run towards you on the shortest trajectory.Not many bosses as such, only a couple of points where you meet more powerful mutants that are annoying to kill. To make up for that, you have a couple of timed RUN AWAY sequences. Yay.One of the time powers is really annoying to set off, as it involves pressing the button for another power twice quickly, which rarely works. I guess this is probably a legacy from consoles, where you have about 8 buttons for everything.The description on the store page isn't quite telling the truth. You do no 'travel seamlessly between 1955 and 2010'. The game pretty much orders you into a rift so you can go back in time, do something to alter the future, then go back into the present to carry on as normal. You don't get the choice of when you want to go back, you just have to.The UglyThe graphics are quickly aging, and not terribly gracefully.Those mutants are not going to win any beauty contests any time soon.Overall score: 74/100. If you like horror FPS games, pick it up, if not, then its probably for the best to leave it. I got it on sale and it was well worth the cost, even if it did leave me with a couple of nights when I regretted playing it in the evening.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Gratuitous Cyrillic is bad, mkay? It can be understandable if you put it in the title for style (though I still grimace at that), but you really shouldn't put it all throughout your game, to the point where you objectives are, "Fiиd Katheяiи aиd escape." Every time, through the entire game. It gets old really, really fast.Now that that little grievance is out of the way, Singularity is fun. It's an interesting tale of the Butterfly Effect and the instability of time travel. The story itself isn't exactly groundbreaking, and some of the narration-particularly the end sequence, which talks for a minute or so and just sort of ends-is poor, but it gets the job done. You're an American military spec ops dude who goes to a Russian island for something they never really specify, and find the island was an old Soviet research facility for an element called E-99 that has time changing properties.♥♥♥♥♥♥goes wrong real quick and you're sucked into the past, where you change history by accident, and come back to find a world run by a brutal dictator who was formerly one of the researchers on the island, which is now overrun by strange abhuman beasts. Now you gotta fix it. There's a sort of twist at the end, too, and while I didn't really see it coming it wasn't exactly M. Night Shyamalan levels of "holy♥♥♥♥♥♥" Still not a bad story by any means, but you really aren't playing Singularity for a riveting tale.What you're playing for is the action. In a similar setup to Bioshock's plasmids, you acquire the TMD (Time Manipulation Device), which allows you to age/de-age objects and people as well as do some other neat♥♥♥♥♥♥ like telekinesis. There's really nothing quite like snatching an enemy RPG out of the air and throwing it back at him. You also have guns. You're honestly going to use the guns a lot more, but the TMD is very useful in interacting with the environment. There's a particular puzzle involving age-crushing a box that the developers really, really, really like. The TMD can one-shot human enemies, instantly aging them to mummies, and has various other effects on the time warped monsters throughout. It takes a lot of energy to do those, though, and while you're constantly swimming in ammo for both your guns and TMD, having to reload after every 2 agings when there's a billion dudes around kinda puts a damper on the useability. So you'll be using your guns a lot, which you can find "weapon tech" to upgrade and get larger magazines, faster reloading, and higher damage. This is where the game makes its biggest mistake. It gives you the Autocannon. It's basically a minigun, and you get it maybe halfway through the game. This isn't a mistake in that it's a bad thing-in fact, quite the opposite. The autocannon is so good I almost only ever used it after getting it. For about half the entire game. It's useful against any enemy, it's high damage, high rate of fire, and the ammo is plenty. Towards the end of the game, **Mild Spoilers** you even get a TMD upgrade that eliminates the use of energy, allowing unlimited use of the TMD's aging attacks against the Russian hordes **/end spoilers** I still used the autocannon anyway. It's just that good, and you feel like a Terminator implacably advancing towards the enemy and cutting them down in a hail of gunfire. Especially with damage reduction and max health upgrades, you feel unstoppable.  There's also the Seeker, an E-99 powered gun that lets you control the bullet mid-flight and is probably the coolest gun in any video game ever. Sadly, you don't get to keep it since switching weapons drops it and the ammo only appears in select areas, but it's always fun while it lasts.Singularity is a good game. The story is feasible enought to provide a backdrop for the action, the gameplay is solid, and autocannon autocannon autocannon. Would recommend.

												Probabaly one of the best Stories I have ever played, well it falls a step behind Half Life 2, but it's hard to bear that.  The way the story unfolds keeps you guessing to what will actually happen at the end of the game.  The ending itself (not going to spoil it) is a shocker none the less. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
Good points:Intriguing storycool enemies, weapons and powers.good pacingLooks really good to this dayGood audio qualityBad points:Game feels very rushed at the endWeapon upgrade system is just badNo real explanation of what upgrades doNo subtitlesvery unbalanced difficulty levelstory has many loopholes and leaves you with so many questionsStoryThe story has a lot of potential in this game, and I'd say they pull of the story about halfway into the game. After that a lot of things start to happen kinda without explanation. So I strongly feel that this game was rushed at the end and that the game kinda suffered for it, this is something I will come back to several times in this review. CharactersYou yourself is much like a Gordon Freeman, voiceless and even faceless in this game. I honestly think this is a bit of a shame, they could have made the story more intriguing and interesting if they character you were playing had feelings and thoughts on the situation. The other characters are pretty standard. There's the good guy, bad guy and the cute girl, these are the three NPC characters you interact with pretty much. They're not well written and you don't care about them but they do their part. Perhaps if the game wasn't rushed this wouldn't have happened.enemies, weapons and powersThe enemy design is really cool in this game, the monsters are scary, gross and challenging to kill. They do lack a bit of variety so you won't see to many different kind of enemies. But the game isn't super long so it's okay. In between fighting monsters you will be shooting at Russians, they are standard NPC's with guns, not much to discuss there. The weapons in this game feel great, look great feel very balanced. The problem I have with them is that there are like 6-7 weapons in total at the end of the game, and I only touched the first three because the others were just introduced to damn late and you have already spent so much upgrade points on the early weapons that it doesn't feel worth it switching to the new ones, this might be a side effect of the game being rushed as well. The weapon upgrade system leaves a lot to wish for, each weapons needs 9 points to be fully upgraded. I'm not even sure if I find a total of 20 upgrade points through the whole game. The powers are probably what carries this game, You have a device on your arm with lets you age specific objects in the world, stop time in an area, levitate and throw objects (kinda like HL2 gravity gun). It's just a ton of fun and the effects look fantastic. They come up with some interesting puzzles with it as well.Difficulty and upgradesMuch like most games this game lets you choose between easy, medium and hard difficulty. I tried normal on my first play-through and I honestly don't think I died a single time. I'm now playing it again on hard and I still have a very easy time. I can play through some parts without any problem and then die seven times in a row in the next area, so the difficulty level feels a bit unbalanced. You can also purchase upgrades for you character and your "gravity gun" in this game, which I think is really fun, The bad part is that you have to find the blueprint for the upgrade in the world and they're sometimes a bit hidden. Meaning that you could potentially miss out on some essential upgrades for you character simply because you didn't look around the room enough. They also don't give you enough points here to upgrade everything but that's fine, it makes you have to choose what to prioritize and what you feel is more important to you. ConclusionThis review might have sound really negative overall but don't get me wrong, I genuinely enjoyed this game a lot and would recommend it to anyone. If you play this game you won't get mad or irritated at all the bad traits I've pointed out, rather you will acknowledge them and perhaps, like me, realize that this game with a bit more time and polishing could easily have been a 10/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												I remember first reading about this game in an issue of Game Informer.  This was roughly 5 or 6 years ago.  To this day, this game is one of the most fun FPS games I've played in a while.  Interacting with your environment by manipulating time was an awesome concept, and it's executed extremely well in Singularity.  That, coupled with your very Bioshock-like grab-bag of powers like pseudo Telekinesis and the ability to slow down time in a certain radius and it makes for very refreshing gameplay.Also, I can honestly say that I haven't had as much fun playing a weapon any game as I have playing with the Seeker.  Seriously, that weapon is some fun♥♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Highly polished, atmospheric, FPS with great controls and pacing.  This is a game that builds to an over powering crescendo.  It doesn't have an original idea, but it's worth the price of admission.  It'll provide 6-8 hours of fun from the campaign.  Too bad this was overlooked when released.  Definitely worth the time if you like shooter and sci fi tropes.

content:

												Easily one of my favorite single player FPS games I've played.  It genuinely shocks me how little recognition this masterpeice recieved.  I definitely recommend this to any FPS lover who is looking for a new reality-twisting, world-warping game complete with weapon upgrade systems, time travel, stealth missions, telekinesis and superb storywriting.  Three thumbs up to Raven Software.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												Im going to start off saying my favorite type of games ever are sifi/doomsday/apocalayptic genres. When I bought this game I thought I was just gonna get a game similar to RAGE, a fun FPS with a decent story and plot. However, I got much more than that with singularity. I found myself on the edge of my chair enjoying a great narrative about time travel and how you can re-write the past to change the future. Dont worry about this game aging poorly either cause I played all of it recently in 2015, and still found this game more than acceptable (coming from a guy who loves graphics a lot). So heres a listPros-Great Narrative-Interesting Gameplay mechanics with a device found in-game-Aged very well (basically meaning it doesnt fell old)-Cool Guns-Awesome Level Design and Themes-RPG level up elements with currency (level up guns, stats, and your TMD)Note that gunplay is average, but I believed designed that way due to the fact that once you start getting upgrades, you become the grim reaper destroying everything in your path, feels like Wolfienstien gunplay. 9/10 Would Travel in Time Again

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												When this game was released i thought nothing of it mostly because it came out when the plague of sub par fps games started. I only decided to try this game once i  saw it on a top 10 hidden gems countdown. I did enjoy my time with the game but i do have a few problems with it that may ruin the game for some people. For starters the game is a measly 5 hours long with little replay value. Yes the game dose have multiple endings but the game saves your progress right before your chose what ending you will get. My next problem is the difficulty. The game in my opinion was way to easy. The tmd made combat interesting but it also made you unstoppable. And the amount of medkits you get are insane. there were many times where i would pass up on 5 in one room because i was maxed out. I only died once and stood there and let 5 monsters chomp on me while i spun around. The few bosses that are there honestly just feel like normal enemies with giant ♥♥♥♥ me blisters on them. The only thing that stuck out in my mind was the weapon selection. you have your basics like a revolver, assault rifle, shotgun, and sniper rifle. But then you start getting guns like the spikeshot that is a railgun with a delay or a grenade launcher that has grenades that you can move on your own. However you are limited to two guns that you can carry except for super weapons. I went through most of the game with the assault rife as my primary for most of the game. and if the is a situation where you can use a gun to its fullest there is convinently a dead body with on laying right in front of you. The super weapons bring the most flavor to the table. The seeker fires an explosive round that you can control in a cool bullet time scene. And then there is a rocket launcher. Ok they may have run out of ideas at that point. The game is fun however and if you looking to kill some time (no pun intended) i recommend picking this game up only on a sale though.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												Game has multiple plot holes which can easily be explained away by the fact that time travel in this game is dependent on the element E-99. If a subject (living or not) does not have any amount of E-99, then time changes upon said subject is nil.Now, depending on the amount of E-99 in a subject (we are talking particles here), then the more "powerful" the time changes is on the subject.That's a big premise to the game. You just can age or make new every and any thing in the game. Graphics are fine. Weapons are nice. You can upgrade your weapons, your time manipulation device, and Renko, which you play as.Story is...meh. Multiple endings. Missing one in my opinion.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												Im going to start off saying my favorite type of games ever are sifi/doomsday/apocalayptic genres. When I bought this game I thought I was just gonna get a game similar to RAGE, a fun FPS with a decent story and plot. However, I got much more than that with singularity. I found myself on the edge of my chair enjoying a great narrative about time travel and how you can re-write the past to change the future. Dont worry about this game aging poorly either cause I played all of it recently in 2015, and still found this game more than acceptable (coming from a guy who loves graphics a lot). So heres a listPros-Great Narrative-Interesting Gameplay mechanics with a device found in-game-Aged very well (basically meaning it doesnt fell old)-Cool Guns-Awesome Level Design and Themes-RPG level up elements with currency (level up guns, stats, and your TMD)Note that gunplay is average, but I believed designed that way due to the fact that once you start getting upgrades, you become the grim reaper destroying everything in your path, feels like Wolfienstien gunplay. 9/10 Would Travel in Time Again

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Wow, Singularity was actually pretty good. The game was released around the same time as Timeshift, both dealing somewhat with using time-changing combat abilities. But hands down, Singularity was a much better game. PLOT - above averageLet's be fair, for the most part of the game, you have no idea why you're running around killing people and charging up some bomb. The basic premise is your character, Renko, saved a dictator in the past, and now the present is under totalitarian control. So now you try to go back and right that wrong. Very linear story, BUT you are presented with 3 possible ending cutscenes, depending on who you shoot at the end. GAMEPLAY - very goodYou have a choice between some very generic guns (assault rifle, shotgun, pistol), but also some very interesting weapons. Here are my favorite:1. Sniper Rifle - has a limited ability to slow down time to let you line up the shot. 2. Seeker Rifle - special weapon with limit supplies that lets you control the path of a sniper bullet. 3. Autocannon - combined with the time-stopping Deadlock, this is hilarously over-powered. I stuck with autocannon and sniper rifle for the majority of the gameplay. The Time-Manipulation Device itself doesn't have very many abilities. I think Deadlock is what everyone uses, just to freeze all the enemies in its bubble. Impulse sends a short-range shockwave, and is very satisfying when enemies get up close to you, and you either blow them away or apart. VISUALLY - nauseatingIt's an old game. Everything looks beige in color, and texture resolutions are very low. The geometry also makes you feel a little sick. SOUND - lackingThere is absolutely no music, just creepy ambient sounds. There's no music even for the title screen! The only music is in the CCCP propaganda films! Gunfire sounds average at most. The voice acting is also mediocre. You don't get attached to anybody. OVERALL - more enjoyable than I thought. A little on the long side, to be honest. Rating: 7/10

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												At the beginning I though, "Wow! this game looks like it will be really cool!" But then after some timeline splitting, story stopped to make sense, and things were not the same. I understand paradoxes are difficult to handle. But they should've at least tried to make them less noticeable. The gameplay itself is ok, some interesting mechanics, mildly interesting characters and one or two good weapons. The premise of the game is completely awesome, at least for me, as I like time travel stuff. However narrative errors and little regard for how timelines work(As old Doc Brown told us XD) lowered my hopes. Anyway I'd still recommend the game on sale, as it looks really cool (I took a lot of screenshots, everywhere) and got some nice and/or spooky moments. But don't expect too much, remember it's average.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 31, 2011
												The plot is as follows: You're a marine sent to investigate a deserted island when suddenly, you find yourself caught in a blast that sends you to an alternate reality. Now you must fight to restore the natural order.Prior to my purchase, I had no idea this game was under the horror genre. While it is occasionally scary, my biggest gripe is that Singularity mostly pulls of "cheap" scares, pumping loud and abrupt music in the face of danger.Singularity's gimmick is its time warping tool. With it, you can restore certain items to its prestine condition or decay it (amusing when used on enemies). You're given a few puzzles to solve and while at first it may seem fun, the gimmick quickly wears thin. The problem is that much of the game mechanic's potential stays untapped. There are about two different puzzles that are recycled throughout. So much could have been done to make this a thinking man's game, but alas, I can only brand Singularity as another generic shooter.Grade: B

												Much better than I expected. The atmosphere and environment of the game really draw you in and the story has its moments of greatness. Some pretty unique enemies and powers are a selling point for gameplay as well. Some negatives would be that the player can get temporarily stuck on some objects and the first time it really became annoying was in a gameplay sequences where I had to run away, of all things. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 25, 2011
												From the get go it is obvious this is a straight up console port. The game doesn't support proper widescreen video resolutions and comes with some serious sound issues. When you get to actually playing the game you'll find the weapon selection lackluster, with a few exceptions. The upgrade functionality feels tacked on and many of the enemies are more annonyances than anything else. The time manipulation mechanic is okay, but I feel they could have done more with it. Multiplayer is a crapshoot and dead.Even so, Singularity does have some redeeming qualities. The story is a real head spinner with 3 seperate endings; although which one you get has nothing to do with your actions throughout the game and instead comes down to one decision at the very end of the game. The plot will have you guessing to the end, and then some. Some of the set peices throughout the story are really amazing, and the boss fights stand out as high points. Overall, I'd give it 5/10. Wait for an under 10$ sale

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Yes, I'm writing to get a piece of coal.  But no matter, this game deserves more love.  You're a soldier sent to investigate an abandoned research station off the coast of Kamchatka.  Wouldn't you know it, you crash and the place is not as abandoned as it looks; in fact it's full of things that want to kill you.There's three  very neat things about this game: 1) the art direction, a wacky combination of Soviet propaganda art plus steampunk; 2) the superpowers you get, which all have to do with time; my favorite is the sniper rifle with bullets you ride; 3) the various endings, all seemingly designed to mess wtih your mind.It's something like Half-Life 2, in fact-- mostly shooting, a few physics puzzles, some cool toys to play with.   I think they could have done a little more with the time mechanics, but it's still a fun ride.

												A hidden gem in the crowded world of Steam games. It doesn't do much new, but it brings a lot of different mechanics together and executes them all well. The over-the-top abilities the Time Manipulation Device (TMD) are always entertaining, and umerous enough to always give you a few options in the heat of combat. Thumbs up from me: it's just fun!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Now this is a nice suprise a bargain on steam at the time I got this game. I read a lot about this game. Like there is a huge budget for this game and there were worries that it wouldn't sell that well. The storyThe game is about a secret Soviet weapon that has been fueled by an element called E99. That can be used to temper with time on a very local scale. It is travelling foreward and backwards in time that eventually clears the reasons and causes of all the troubles and combat you are in. There are some good suprises in the story and some very good "shock and awe" moments. I really enjoyed it all I must admit. I couldn't really stop playing till the end of the story and thus the game. The theme "time travel" always fascinated me from the time I saw the movie and read the book Time Machine by Orson Wells. So that of time travel is a very big plus or pro for me. Way of tellingThe story telling is being done with ocassional cutscenes that reminded me of Call Of Duty in a way. You start out with a search of a secret Soviet base on an remote island close to the Russian border. You search the base or island I must say for clues what happened in the past and why there such strange mutated creatures roaming around the island? This gave me the feeling of the game Stalker where a nuclear accident also created strange mutations among the wildlife or even to the human inhabitants. Ocassionally you see ghosts from the past acting out scenes of mayhem that happened years ago. Those scenes reminded me of the game FEAR somehow. Where you also had flashbacks via ghostly like scenes. That sented chills down my spine. Film and sound footageThe story is good and even backed up with some very amusing films and sound footage that have been scattered around the base. Those recordings you can listen to or even see in film projectors still functioning at the base. Most of the time the have that eerie looking sound or damaged footage of aging of some other violent event. Graphics and soundsThe graphics are superb and the sounds are very well done. Although the story is very amusing to say the least. It also makes the maps a little linear in a way. There is no free roaming around the maps like you can with so many roleplaying games. But do not let that spoil the fun. There are still plenty of places to search for loot like ammo and the E99 fuel metals. You have to find certain characters in the game. Get this tool or this element find it take it somewhere and all backed up by a more or less logical story line. Do I recommend it? Oh yes you should try this game if you like the elements of timetravel and some scary horror moments in a game. A game for mature playersSo I must add this game is for the mature players that like some gory scenes from time to time. There are a lot of dead corpses  some even impaled (like in games like Doom) and bloodbaths. When you shoot enemies they lose limps and other body parts by the impact of the bullets. There is even an time weapon where you can "age" people very fast. A very good game & get it if you canSo be warned or informed what ever you like. This is a good well done game. You can see there has been put a lot of effort in this game. So I do recommend this game. Go for it if you like the things mentioned above.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Let me preface this review by saying I waited 4 years to play this game. I liked the look of it when it released in 2010 but could never bring myself to buy it at full price. I picked it up on sale from Steam for about $8 and for that price is it probably worth it.The Singularity isn't a bad game in any way but it relies to much on being derivative of it's peers and often makes the classic modern FPS mistake of using a brown color pallet and heavy industrial level design.The shooting itself is good if not great, the enemies are varied (shades of Doom, Wolfenstein, Half Life and even COD can be seen here) and weapons and your TMD (read Half life 2 gravity gun mix with some other stuff) can be upgraded. Towards the end of the game you can do some really neat things with your TMD/weapon combos that keep combat fun and lively.The story is a little convoluted and the characters are muddy. Much like the TMD rips off Half Life 2's gravity gun in some respects so the cast here are retreads of the characters in the older game. The female lead is a poor man's Alyx Vance but does a serviceable job guiding you through the story. I just had a hard time connecting with the characters, although I will say the multiple endings to the game is a nice touch!The TMD does also allow for some minor puzzle elements that can initially seem taxing but once you have seen one of about the 3 or 4 puzzles that are used through the game you can quickly identify and solve them. In the end what strikes you as an “oh wow nice touch” trick the first time ends up feeling played about by the 25th.This leads me onto my biggest gripe with the game: the level design. The Singularity has some amazing potential and wastes it utterly with brown industrial environ after brown industrial environ. The levels set in the past are, varied, bright, colorful and full of unique little touches that made me want to explore this cold war era lab (it really reminded me of half life 1, a living breathing facility I wanted to inhabit not just visit). It is a crying shame that you never visit them for more than 10 minutes at a time. These levels are also filled with Russian soliders that act half way intelligently and are fun to fight. The modern levels by contrast are by the numbers brown boxes that remind me of quake 1 or painkiller with less character. The enemies that inhabit them are varied and some are fun to fight but too many simply charge at you. Once you acquire some decent weapons and TMD upgrades they become a chore to fight.The split between old and modern sums up the Singularity well for every good moment there is something dull and bland. A unique feature or moment here is followed by a dull 30 minute sepia section shortly after. If only Raven had stuck to using the 50's setting throughout the game we may have had a truly unique and classic game on our hands. It's still a decent shooter and well worth a blast through if you can get it for under $10 but I came away feeling happy I played it but sad that it wasn't as good as it could have been.7/10

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												Obviously has aspects from other games, most notably Bioshock, and doesn't look that great when compared to them. However, taken on its own it's a solid FPS with good controls, solid weapons and a decent enough storyline.Singularity isn't groundbreaking and now I've completed it I doubt I'll replay it any time soon. What it is is a fun FPS that is well worth playing through.Oddest thing for me is that many aspects of the game mirror Bioshock, which is a game I both love and loath. Singularity simply doesn't quite manage to pull off the atmosphere or the immersive world that Bioshock does, on the other hand I find the controls for Bioshock horribly clunky  while Singularity is beautifully smooth. In a year or so if I'm looking for an 'experience' I'll load up Bioshock... if I'm looking for a bit of FPS no-brain violence I may well choose Singularity.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												Join one AMERICAN man on his quest to become a time wizard who can cause death through willpower alone! It's Russian Call of Duty-Shock! Very linear, story that completely falls apart, but damn fun. Singularity would've been much better if it didn't take itself as seriously.Your character is completely throw away, half of the other leads hardly do anything, and level design is hamfisted and forced. You get amazing guns, but you can't carry around the most original one (allows you to curve bullets in slow-mo). Nice items are placed in action sequence areas, forcing you to stop combat to collect them.And yet the combat is gleeful. Every gun is ridiculously strong, but enemies still swarm well enough to make hard mode challenging. The sniper rifle one-shots everything no matter where you hit and lets you slow time. Controllable rolley-polley grenade launcher. Stasis bubble lets you shoot 3 guys in the head, and watch them all tumble to the floor simultaneously. A fun romp.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												I love time travel stories - and this delivers!*minor spoilers*Yes, it is very linear. Yes, the story is not *that* original. And yes, in normal difficulty the game throws medipacks and ammo at you continously so that you never need to worry. There are some easy-to-solve switch puzzles that make for rather quiet situations, followed by explosive killfests with mangled bodies flying around. The weapons are awesome, especially the "experimental" stuff like the steerable bullet that make your targets explode in a fountain of flesh and blood. Very satisfying :)Although the story isn't outstanding, it is brilliantly told! Scripted events, explosions, dialogues, story twists... the Half Life-Formula is working great. The level design is good enough to let you dive into the world - which is disturbed by invisible walls you often walk into. Overall I was entertained from start to end - and that is what I want when I play a science fiction FPS ;)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												I awaited a bit long for a sale before buying this game; I must say that I shouldn't have awaited so long and just bought it at full price, because it worth it.Around the internet you'll see some people comparing Singularity to Half-Life 2 and Bioshock, so I'll compare too, but I'll show what points those games has in common with Singularity, so you can form your own opinion. Story You play as captain Nathaniel Renko, who comes to a misterious island called Katorga-12 after the military has received some signs of radiation while its radar was passing by the Eastern Russia; when you arrive at the island, it is a desolate place, abandoned long ago for unknown reasons, while some kind of military reasearch has gone completely wrong when the russians discovered a new element called E-99. Gameplay Some people say that this desolated island has some resemblance with Bioshock's rapture or even Half-Life 2's City 17, because of the abandoned post-apocalyptic feel it has; but Katorga-12 has its own charm, you can think it as a second Chernobyl (if you played the Stalker series you'll know what I'm talking about). People who used to live there abandoned their normal lives for good, leaving papers on the tables, schools are full of children drawnings and kitchens are still filled with canned food and pots. It's a wonderful game, full of places to explore and learn about what happened in the island, and Singularity really rewards exploration, so please, don't rush while playing this game, take your time because you'll be rewarded with secrets that only the devs at Raven could have done so well. Most of the plot is explained by notes you find scattered around the buildings and audio logs. Some are well hidden, requiring even a bit of thinking before you can reach them, which I myself think it's just awesome. This is a feature that you'll find in Bioshock, but in Singularity I find it particularly better, because the voice acting is just perfect (at the beggining of the game you'll hear some audio logs made by the children themselves, trust me, it'll give you some chills). There is a couple more features that will bring Bioshock to mind, for instance the way you collect items in the game: you must interact with them pressing a key, only ammo you can actually pick up running above them; the health system isn't regenerative as in most shooters, you must collect aid packs to use later pressing another key, as with Bioshock. Singularity has kind of the same pace as Bioshock, that is having you searching the place for clues, secrets and items, then entering in some fire-fights. During the action scenes you can use a very well selected variety of weapons, and it doesn't limit itself with the everyday shotgun and machine gun: you have weapons that let you literaly guide the bullet, and even a grenade launcher that let you "drive" the grenade around the environment; even the usual sniper rifle has a feature that let you slow down time to aim well at your targets. Unlike in Bioshock, in Singularity you really feel the 'oomph' of the weapons, they aren't just pea shooters and the enemies aren't bullet sponges who just loves to break your immersion. I wouldn't call Singularity a shooter, because it has more to offer; but when you have to shoot somebody, it does well, with solid shooter mechanics, reload animations and weapon upgrades.The main feature of the game is presented by the Time Manipulating Device, or TMD, which works as a glove that you wear in your left hand. With it, you can solve puzzles buy aging and renewing some objects, like crates, stairs and machinery. As you progress within that game, you can upgrade it with new powers, just like you do with the plasmids found in Bioshock, but as I said, Singularity has its own charm, it only takes inspiration in Bioshock, although sometimes I felt as it was the other way around, because everything Singularity does, it does better than Bioshock. These new powers let you launch pulse explosions, create bubbles that stops time within it, age enemies until they're just a pile of dust and manipulate objects just like the Gravity Gun (again, Half-Life 2).Singularity has a total of three endings that conclude the narrative in three awesome and distinct ways, that you would finish in something like 8 hours or so. Sounds Everything in this game sounds good: the voice acting, gun shots, explosions, the russian lines spoken by some enemies, the soundtrack that changes accordingly... It's everything well done. Technically I saw some people saying it runs badly, but it is one of those games that was completely polished and well optimized; I could reach 120fps (it doesn't have fps limit as most games out there), and my PC is kind of mid range: i5 2400 3.10GHz, 8GB ram, Windows 7 64bits and a GTX650 1GB.So, if you are the kind of gamer who likes plot oriented games, with a good shooting mechanics and full of out of the ordinary places to explore, just like Half-Life and Bioshock, you definitely should give SIngularity a go. But don't expect a rip off, because this game was well done, it has all of the Raven style that old gamers love and it's really one of its kind.

												I bought this game as a cheap deal with no knowledge how good or bad it is, it looked good though. It was a good buy. Singularity features good graphics, simply gameplay and the element of time travel and time alteration, two things that can make things awesome. With a special device you can instantly kill enemies, repair or destroy items by sending them through time and even travel back in time sometimes to alter the future, with the consequences visible only moments later. It's interesting to find out what happened on the island, how things came the way they are and at the end of everything you can make a choice to alter the future the way YOU want. Though the endings are all a bit lame, the gameplay is good, the developers could've made more out of the time travel aspect, but maybe we see a sequel sometime.Overall a solid title.

												For a time travel story, it was overly simple. It had so much wasted potential. Same thing with the puzzles in this game, too simple. The first puzzle is OUTSTANDING, but then they recycle that same exact idea over and over and OVER again with nothing new. There's a part in this game where you have to fight a ♥♥♥♥♥ of infected with a pistol. That was unholy difficulty, even on normal mode. INTERESTINGLY enough, that's the ONLY difficult part of the game. The entire time you basically play as a god, completely destroying everything in your way. Overall, it wasted many good opportunities, and was JUST ok. Cross Bioshock with Fallout 3, with HL2, dumb down the story and difficulty BAM! You got yourself Singularity. Not that it's bad, it's just not nearly as good as it could have been.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												Paranormal sci-fi horror with temporal-weaponry. 2nd playthrough. Definitely worth playing again. Story revolves around a newly discovered (ficticious) element, e99, and the island Katorga-12 where it is exclusively found. E99 holds enormous energetic potential, but is unstable, mutates organic life, and distorts time where it abounds. You are a captain in the u.s. military sent to the island; thought abandoned, to investigate an energy signature which is blinding u.s. spy satelittes. Upon arriving, a temporal wake engulfs you, sending you back in time to 1955. There you find yourself in the same lab facility as it burns. Without hesitation, you rescue a scientist, Demichev. Only before a 2nd temporal wake brings you back to 2010. Demichev was one of two lead scientists heading research into the element and its application. He will continue recklessly pursuing his controversial research without regard for life. His research results in the development and collapse of the singularity, it kills 1000s instantly and mutates any remaning survivors on the island. The result is a paranormal, atemporal mess, torn by violence. Failing to be disuaded, Demichev develops e99 weaponry and quickly rises to power, empowering Russia to conquer the world. The game is primarily about restoring the timeline, but throughout the game you encounter cryptic warnings, written in messages only you can reveal. Perhaps left by a future-you? or by MIR-12? A mysterious organization with knowlecge they couldn't possibly posess, and whose intentions are unclear. As far as enemies, the mutant survivors of the island, warped by the energy of singularity collapse are almost alien. They move incredibly fast, in and out of phase, or can teleport. Others have heightened hearing, but are blind. Still others have become incredibly large. Temporal rifts frequent the game where you can witness events in the past occuring concurrently with the present; revealing the tragic deaths of the inhabitants. Recordings also build this story and reveal what happened in the time since you traveled to 1955. Mostly detailing the exodus of survivors and their horrific deaths attempting to leave. Weapons are also e99 based. Guided rounds, sniper that can slow down time for precise shots, and standard-shooter semi-auto shotgun, assault rifle, and minigun. The most fun is with your TMD, a device you are led to early in the game which embues you with great power. You can create time manipulation fields that age/rejuvenate items or people/mutants, timelocks which freeze time, you can pull things between time-periods, and jump between the years 1955 and 2010. Futher more, you can unleash a blast of energy from your palm that will send enemies flying or will rip them apart. Graphics were out of date even for it's time, but it's just bloody fun to play. And the story line is eery, but enjoyable. Short, but worth your attention, especially if you're into paranormal or sci-fi horror games. Fans of the metro or STALKER series would enjoy, although the feel is much more arcade.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Wow, Singularity was actually pretty good. The game was released around the same time as Timeshift, both dealing somewhat with using time-changing combat abilities. But hands down, Singularity was a much better game. PLOT - above averageLet's be fair, for the most part of the game, you have no idea why you're running around killing people and charging up some bomb. The basic premise is your character, Renko, saved a dictator in the past, and now the present is under totalitarian control. So now you try to go back and right that wrong. Very linear story, BUT you are presented with 3 possible ending cutscenes, depending on who you shoot at the end. GAMEPLAY - very goodYou have a choice between some very generic guns (assault rifle, shotgun, pistol), but also some very interesting weapons. Here are my favorite:1. Sniper Rifle - has a limited ability to slow down time to let you line up the shot. 2. Seeker Rifle - special weapon with limit supplies that lets you control the path of a sniper bullet. 3. Autocannon - combined with the time-stopping Deadlock, this is hilarously over-powered. I stuck with autocannon and sniper rifle for the majority of the gameplay. The Time-Manipulation Device itself doesn't have very many abilities. I think Deadlock is what everyone uses, just to freeze all the enemies in its bubble. Impulse sends a short-range shockwave, and is very satisfying when enemies get up close to you, and you either blow them away or apart. VISUALLY - nauseatingIt's an old game. Everything looks beige in color, and texture resolutions are very low. The geometry also makes you feel a little sick. SOUND - lackingThere is absolutely no music, just creepy ambient sounds. There's no music even for the title screen! The only music is in the CCCP propaganda films! Gunfire sounds average at most. The voice acting is also mediocre. You don't get attached to anybody. OVERALL - more enjoyable than I thought. A little on the long side, to be honest. Rating: 7/10
